{{Infobox person | name = Adele Lewisohn Lehman | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Adele Lewisohn | birth_date = May 17, 1882 | birth_place = [[New York City]] | death_date = August 11, 1965 | death_place = [[Purchase, New York]] | death_cause = [[cerebral hemorrhage]] | residence = [[Purchase, New York]] | nationality = United States | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma_mater = | networth = | occupation = | spouse = [[Arthur Lehman]] | children = [[Dorothy Lehman Bernhard]]
[[Frances Lehman Loeb]]
[[Helen Lehman Buttenwieser]] | parents = Emma Cahn Lewisohn
[[Adolph Lewisohn]] | relations = [[Leonard Lewisohn (philanthropist)|Leonard Lewisohn]] (uncle)
[[Jesse Lewisohn]] (cousin)
[[Alice Lewisohn]] (cousin)
[[Irene Lewisohn]] (cousin)
[[Robert A. Bernhard]] (grandson)
[[Mayer Lehman]] (father-in-law) | website = }} '''Adele Lewisohn Lehman''' (May 17, 1882 – August 11, 1965) was an American philanthropist and member of the [[Lehman family]]. ==Biography== Adele Lewisohn Lehman was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family on May 17, 1882 in [[New York City]], the daughter of Emma (née Cahn) and [[Adolph Lewisohn]].[https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/lehman-adele-lewisohn Jewish Women's Archive: "Adele Lewisohn Lehman 1882–1965" by Laurie Sokol] retrieved October 30, 2015 Her father and his brothers (Julius and [[Leonard Lewisohn (philanthropist)|Leonard]]) were known as "copper kings" after making their fortune opening copper mines to fuel demand for copper wire with the advent of electricity; her father was also a leader in prison reform. Lehman attended the Anne Brown School and then [[Barnard College]]. ==Philanthropy== Coming from wealth and marrying into wealth, Lehman was a prominent philanthropist. Although Lehman was an honorary chairperson for the [[Federation of Jewish Philanthropies]] (founded by her husband Arthur Lehman), most of her philanthropic efforts were secular. She was a board member of the New York Service for the Orthopedically Handicapped; was both a founder and board member of the Arthur Lehman Counseling Service; served as the president of the [[P.S. 157|East Side Free School for Crippled Children]];{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wLtJAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA143&lpg=PA143&dq=Adele+Lewisohn+Lehman&source=bl&ots=YyA6Jj7Oj2&sig=NVFPGGFMFwanlKF4H-o4BnwrqEc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjsor3DjbrWAhUn_IMKHcLoBFg4ChDoAQg-MAQ#v=onepage&q=Adele%20Lewisohn%20Lehman&f=false|first=|last=|title=Bulletin Joint Distribution Committee Representing American Jewish Relief Committee, Central Relief Committee, People's Relief Committee|pages=143 |publisher=|date=September 2016|ISBN=}} the Purple Box, an outlet for the sale of goods made by disabled women; served as director of the Adoption Bureau; was a board member of the New York Board of Charities; a member of the Crusade for Children (part of the [[Child Welfare League of America]]); served as vice president of the [[League of Women Voters]] until 1945; and served on the board of directors for the [[Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York]] (elected 1947); and was a board member of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society. In 1957, the [[Lehman Hall|Adele Lehman Hall]] at Barnard College was named in her honor; the hall held the Wollman Library until 2015. ==Personal life== On November 25, 1901, she married [[Arthur Lehman]] (1873-1936), son of Babette (née Newgass) and [[Mayer Lehman]]. Arthur belong to the prominent Lehman family: his father was a co-founder of [[Lehman Brothers]]; his brother [[Herbert H. Lehman]], was a former governor and senator of New York; and his brother, [[Irving Lehman]], was a former judge of the New York state court of appeals. They had three daughters: [[Dorothy Lehman Bernhard]] (1904-1969), [[Helen Lehman Buttenwieser]] (1905-1989), and [[Frances Lehman Loeb]] (1906-1996). Lehman died of a [[cerebral hemorrhage]] on August 11, 1965 at her home in Purchase, New York. Lehman belonged to [[Congregation Emanu-El of New York|Temple Emanu-El]] in [[Manhattan]]. She was also a championship tennis player and won thirty-eight competitions. Lehman and her husband collected paintings, decorative arts, bronzes, ceramics, and tapestries from the 14th to 20th centuries.[http://research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord.php?-action=browse&-recid=7233 The Frick Collection: "Lehman, Adele Lewisohn, 1882-1965"] retrieved September 22, 2017 Their collection consisted of [[Italian primitives]], and works by [[Henry Raeburn]], [[Jean Baptiste Greuze]], [[Francesco Guardi]], [[Corneille de Lyon]], [[Claude Lorrain]], [[Gustave Courbet]], [[Jan Van Goyen]], [[Aert van der Neer]], [[Albert Cuyp]], [[Jacob Isaacksz van Ruisdael]], and [[Thomas Lawrence]]. After the death of her husband, she continued to expand her collection purchasing works by [[Van Gogh]], [[Rousseau]], [[Paul Gauguin]], [[Renoir]], [[Eugene Boudin]], [[Odilon Redon]], [[George Seurat]], [[Paul Signac]], [[Édouard Vuillard]], [[Matisse]], [[Derain]], [[James Abbott McNeill Whistler|Whistler]], [[Childe Hassam]], and [[Degas]]. Upon her death, she left much of her collection to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] and the [[Fogg Museum]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lehman, Adele Lewisohn}} [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1965 deaths]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Lehman family]]

{{Infobox company |name = Biogen Inc. |logo = Biogen.svg |type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{unbulleted list | {{NASDAQ|BIIB}} | [[NASDAQ-100]] component | [[S&P 100]] component | [[S&P 500]] component }} |founded = 1978 (from merger) |founders = [[Kenneth Murray (biologist)|Kenneth Murray]]
[[Phillip Allen Sharp]]
[[Walter Gilbert]]
Heinz Schaller
[[Charles Weissmann]] |key_people = Stelios Papadopoulos {{small|([[Chairman]])}}
Michel Vounatsos {{small|([[CEO]])}} |industry = [[Biotechnology]] |products = Alprolix, [[Interferon beta-1a#Avonex|Avonex]], Eloctate, [[4-Aminopyridine|Fampyra]], [[Obinutuzumab|Gazyva*]], [[Interferon beta-1a#Plegridy|Plegridy]], [[Rituximab|Rituxan*]], [[Dimethyl fumarate|Tecfidera]], [[Natalizumab|Tysabri]], [[Nusinersen|Spinraza]] | revenue = {{increase}} {{US$|12.274 billion|link=yes}} {{small|(2017)}}{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/875045/000087504518000005/biib-20171231x10k.htm |title=Biogen Inc. 2017 Annual Report (Form 10-K) |date=January 2018 |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] |website=sec.gov}} | operating_income = {{increase}} {{US$|5.344 billion}} {{small|(2017)}} | net_income = {{decrease}} {{US$|2.539 billion}} {{small|(2017)}} | assets = {{increase}} {{US$|23.653 billion}} {{small|(2017)}} | equity = {{increase}} {{US$|12.613 billion}} {{small|(2017)}} | num_employees = ~7,300 {{small|(December 2017)}} | location_city = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], U.S. | website = {{URL|biogen.com}} | footnotes= *Commercialized by Genentech/Roche }} '''Biogen Inc.''' (previously known as '''Biogen Idec''') is an American [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[biotechnology]] company based in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], specializing in the discovery, development, and delivery of therapies for the treatment of [[neurodegenerative]], [[hematologic]], and [[autoimmune diseases]] to patients worldwide. == History == Biogen was founded in 1978 in [[Geneva]]{{cite web |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2012/12/04/biogen-idec-biotechs-comeback-kid/ |title = Biotech's Comeback Kid |publisher = Forbes |accessdate=2012-12-04}} by several prominent biologists, including [[Kenneth Murray (biologist)|Kenneth Murray]] of the [[University of Edinburgh]], [[Phillip Allen Sharp]] of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], [[Walter Gilbert]] of [[Harvard]] (who served as CEO during the start-up phase), [[Heinz Schaller]], [[University of Heidelberg]] and [[Charles Weissmann]], [[University of Zurich]] (who contributed the first product [[interferon alpha]]). Gilbert and Sharp were subsequently honored with [[Nobel Prize]]s: Gilbert was recognized in 1980 with the [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] for his work in understanding [[DNA sequencing]], while Sharp received the [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] in 1993 for his discovery of [[split gene]]s. In 2003, Biogen merged with [[San Diego, California]]-based IDEC Pharmaceuticals (formed in 1985 by [[Ivor Royston]], [[Howard Birndorf]] and others) and adopted the name Biogen Idec.{{cite web |title=Biogen and IDEC Pharmaceuticals Announce Merger To Create a New Biotechnology Industry Leader |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/875045/000104746903021993/a2113458zex-99_1.htm|quote="IDEC — Founded in 1985 to develop monoclonal antibodies. Founders include Ivor Royston, Howard Birndorf, Richard Miller and Brook Byers" |website=Exhibit 99.1 |accessdate=1 December 2018}} After the merger, Biogen Idec became the 3rd largest Biotechnology company in the world.{{cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/24/business/idec-to-merge-with-biogen-in-6.8-billion-deal.html|title = Idec to Merge With Biogen in $6.8 Billion Deal|publisher = New York Times |accessdate=2003-06-24}} Following shifts in research core areas, the company has since shortened its name, reverting to simply Biogen.{{cite web|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/biogen-drops-idec-from-name-1427113639|title = Biogen Drops Idec From Name|publisher = Wall Street Journal|accessdate=2015-03-23}} Biogen stock is a component of several stock indices such as the [[S&P 100]], [[S&P 500]], [[S&P 1500]], and [[NASDAQ-100]] and the company is listed on the [[NASDAQ]] stock exchange under the ticker symbol, BIIB.{{cite web|url = http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/biib|title = Biogen Idec Inc. Stock Quote & Summary Data|publisher = NASDAQ}} In May 2006, the company announced it would acquire cancer specialist, Conforma Therapeutics for $250 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pharmatimes.com/news/biogen_idec_agrees_to_buy_swiss_company_fumapharm_996746|title=Biogen Idec agrees to buy Swiss company Fumapharm|last=PharmaTimes|date=2006-06-01|website=www.pharmatimes.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}} Later in the same month, the company announced its intention to acquire Fumapharm AG, consolidating ownership of [[Fumaderm]] and [[BG-12]], an oral [[fumarate]], which is being studied for the treatment of [[multiple sclerosis]] and [[psoriasis]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20060531005276/en/Biogen-Idec-Acquire-Fumapharm-AG-Consolidates-Ownership|title=Biogen Idec to Acquire Fumapharm AG; Consolidates Ownership of Oral Compound BG-12 Being Studied for Multiple Sclerosis|website=www.businesswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}} In January 2007, the company announced it would acquire Syntonix Pharmaceuticals for up to $120 million, gaining Syntonix's lead product for hemophilia B as well as the technology for developing inhalable treatments.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/biogen-to-buy-syntonix-120m-deal|title=Biogen to buy Syntonix in $120M deal {{!}} FierceBiotech|website=www.fiercebiotech.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20070104005533/en/Biogen-Idec-Acquire-Syntonix|title=Biogen Idec to Acquire Syntonix|website=www.businesswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}} In February 2013, [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] broke the news that Biogen was planning the pay [[Élan|Elan]] $3.25 billion for the full rights to [[Tysabri]], used to treat multiple sclerosis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-02-06/biogen-to-pay-elan-3-25-billion-for-full-tysabri-rights|title=Biogen to Pay Elan $3.25 Billion for Full Tysabri Rights|date=2013-02-06|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-28}} In January 2015 the company announced it will acquire [[Convergence Pharmaceuticals]] for up to $675 million, with the acquisition aiming to accelerate the development of Convergence's pipeline, in-particular [[Raxatrigine|CNV1014802]] – a Phase II small molecule sodium channel blocking candidate.{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/biogen-idec-snaps-up-convergence-for-up-to-675m/81250789/|title=Biogen Idec Snaps Up Convergence for Up-to-$675M - GEN News Highlights - GEN|publisher=}} In October 2015 the company announced it will lay off 11% of its workforce, effective immediately.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/biogen-layoffs-cutting-11-of-workforce-2015-10|title=Biogen is cutting 11% of its workforce|publisher=}} ===Bioverativ=== In May 2016 the company announced that it will [[Corporate spin-off|spin off]] its hemophilia drug business (Eloctate and Alprolix) into a public company.{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-biogen-hemophilia-idUSKCN0XU15E | title=Biogen to spin off hemophilia drug business into a public company | work=Reuters | date=May 3, 2016 | accessdate=May 3, 2016 | author=D'Souza, Savio}} In August, the company announced that the spun off company would be called [[Bioverativ]], in order to show heritage with Biogen.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercepharma.com/pharma/biogen-introduces-spinoff-bioverativ-amid-takeover-buzz|title=Amid takeover chatter, Biogen introduces hemophilia spinoff Bioverativ - FiercePharma|publisher=}} The company will trade on the NASDAQ exchange under the ticker symbol BIVV{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/financialpost/20160809005296/en/Biogen-Announces-Bioverativ-Hemophilia-Focused-Company|title=Biogen Announces Bioverativ as Name of New Hemophilia-Focused Company {{!}} Business Wire|website=www.businesswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-28}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2016/08/09/biogen-unveils-name-for-hemophilia-drug-spinoff-bioverativ/2EjLRgOOGpOZJECl3nO4yH/story.html|title=Biogen unveils name for hemophilia drug spinoff: Bioverativ - The Boston Globe|publisher=}} and will look to be spun off in early 2017.{{cite web|url=http://media.biogen.com/press-release/hemophilia-spin/biogen-announces-bioverativ-name-new-hemophilia-focused-company|title=Biogen Announces Bioverativ as Name of New Hemophilia-Focused Company - Biogen Media|publisher=}} ===Acquisition history=== The following is an illustration of the company's major mergers and acquisitions and historical predecessors (this is not a comprehensive list): {{clade | style=font-size:90%;line-height:110% |thickness=0 |label1=Biogen |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |label1=Biogen IDEC |1={{clade |label1= |1={{clade |1=Biogen
(Founded 1978) }} |label2= |2= {{clade |1= IDEC Pharmaceuticals }} }} |label2= |2= {{clade |1= Conforma Therapeutics
(Acq 2006) }} }} |label2= |2= {{clade |1= Fumapharm AG
(Acq 2006) }} }} |label2= |2= {{clade |1= Syntonix Pharmaceuticals
(Acq 2007) }} }} |label2= |2= {{clade |1= Convergence Pharmaceuticals
(Acq 2015) }} }} }} == Finances == For the fiscal year 2017, Biogen reported earnings of US$2.539 billion, with an annual revenue of US$12.274 billion, an increase of 7.2% over the previous fiscal cycle. Biogen's shares traded at over $289 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$63 billion in November 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/BIIB/biogen/revenue|title=Biogen Revenue 2006-2018 {{!}} BIIB|website=www.macrotrends.net|access-date=2018-11-05}} The company ranked 245 on the 2018 [[Fortune 500]] list of the largest United States corporations by revenue.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/list/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2018: Who Made the List|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-25}} {| class="wikitable float-left" style="text-align: right;" !Year !Revenue

Biogen and Swedish Orphan Biovitrum (Sobi) are collaborators in the development and commercialization of ALPROLIX. {{cite web |url = http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2014/04/07/does-biogen-idec-inc-have-a-new-blockbuster-hemoph.aspx |title = Does Biogen Idec Inc Have a New Blockbuster Hemophilia Therapy? |publisher = The Motley Fool |accessdate=2014-07-04 }} |- |[[Avonex|AVONEX®]] ([[interferon beta-1a]])||Relapsing forms of [[multiple sclerosis]]||1996 ||1997 ||Includes the AVONEX PEN auto-injector and the AVOSTARTGRIP titration kit approved in the U.S. in 2012.{{cite web |url = http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Treating-MS/Medications/Avonex |title = Avonex |publisher = National MS Society }} |- |ELOCTATE™ [Antihemophilic Factor (Recombinant), Fc Fusion Protein]||Control and prevention of bleeding episodes, perioperative (surgical) management and routine prophylaxis in adults and children with [[hemophilia A]]||2014 ||1999||Biogen and Swedish Orphan Biovitrum (Sobi) are collaborators in the development and commercialization of ELOCTATE.{{cite web |url = http://www.thepharmaletter.com/article/biogen-idec-s-eloctate-gains-fda-approval |title = Biogen Idec’s Eloctate gains FDA approval |publisher = The Pharma Letter |accessdate=2014-09-06 }} |- |FAMPYRA (prolonged-release [[4-Aminopyridine|fampridine]] tablets)||[[Multiple sclerosis]] (Walking ability)||2010 ||2011 ||Marketed by Biogen in markets outside of the United States. Commercialized in the United States as AMPYRA (dalfampridine) Extended Release Tablets, by [[Acorda Therapeutics]].{{cite web |url = http://www.mstrust.org.uk/atoz/fampridine.jsp |title = Fampridine (Fampyra) |publisher = MS Trust }} |- |FUMADERM (fumaric acid esters)||[[Psoriasis]] German use || ||1994 (Germany only) ||Approved in Germany. Acquired in acquisition of Fumapharm AG in 2006.{{cite web |url = http://www.firstwordpharma.com/node/149468 |title = Biogen Idec enters deal to acquire Fumapharm |publisher = First Word Pharma |accessdate=2006-05-31 }} |- |GAZYVA ([[obinutuzumab]])||[[Chronic lymphocytic leukemia]]||2013 ||2014 ||The first medicine approved with the FDA's Breakthrough Therapy Designation and is also currently in Phase 3 trials for NHL and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Currently commercialized in the United States by Genentech, a wholly owned subsidiary of Roche.{{cite web |url = http://www.fda.gov/newsevents/newsroom/pressannouncements/ucm373209.htm |title = FDA approves Gazyva for chronic lymphocytic leukemia |publisher = FDA.gov |accessdate=2013-01-11 }} |- |SPINRAZA ([[nusinersen]]) |[[Spinal muscular atrophy]] |2016 |2017 |The first drug approved for the treatment of [[spinal muscular atrophy]], developed in collaboration with [[Ionis Pharmaceuticals]].{{cite journal|last1=Wadman|first1=Meredith|title=Updated: FDA approves drug that rescues babies with fatal neurodegenerative disease|journal=Science|date=23 December 2016|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/12/novel-drug-rescues-babies-fatal-neurodegenerative-disease}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/surprise-drug-approval-is-holiday-gift-for-biogen-1482856447|title=Surprise Drug Approval Is Holiday Gift for Biogen|last=Grant|first=Charley|date=2016-12-27|work=|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-12-27|via=}} |- |[[Plegridy|PLEGRIDY]] (peginterferon beta-1a)||Relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis||2014{{cite web |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/15/ma-biogen-idec-idUSnBw155610a+100+BSW20140815 |title = Biogen Idec’s PLEGRIDY(Peginterferon Beta-1a) Approved in the US for the Treatment of Multiple Sclerosis |publisher = Reuters }} ||2014{{cite web |url = http://www.thepharmaletter.com/article/biogen-idec-s-plegridy-approved-in-europe-for-relapsing-remitting-multiple-sclerosis |title = Biogen Idec’s Plegridy approved in Europe for relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis |publisher = The Pharma Letter }} || |- |RITUXAN ([[rituximab]])||[[Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma]] (NHL) Anti-TNF Refractory Rheumatoid Arthritis ANCA-Associated Vasculitis [[Chronic lymphocytic leukemia]] ||1997{{cite web |url = http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/druginfo/fda-rituximab |title = FDA Approval for Rituximab |publisher = National Cancer Institute }} 2006{{cite web |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/10/21/biogen-roche-idUSN2110240020101021 |title = UPDATE 1-Roche, Biogen end dispute over Rituxan follow-ons |publisher = Reuters |accessdate=2010-10-21 }} 2011{{cite web |url = http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm251946.htm |title = FDA approves Rituxan to treat two rare disorders |publisher = FDA.gov |accessdate=2011-04-19 }} ||1998 (as MabThera) ||The first monoclonal antibody for cancer developed by IDEC, prior to merging with Biogen. Currently commercialized by Roche and its subsidiary, Genentech. |- |TECFIDERA (dimethyl fumarate)||Relapsing forms of [[multiple sclerosis]]||2013{{cite web |url = http://www.thepharmaletter.com/article/cell-therapeutics-buys-zevalin-from-biogen-idec-for-10m-with-up-to-20m-extra-plus-milestones |title = Cell Therapeutics buys Zevalin from Biogen Idec for $10M, with up to $20M extra plus milestones |publisher = The Pharma Letter |accessdate=2007-09-03 }} ||2014{{cite web |url = http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Treating-MS/Medications/Tecfidera%E2%84%A2 |title = Tecifedra |publisher = National MS Society }} || |- |TYSABRI ([[natalizumab]])||Relapsing-remitting [[multiple sclerosis]]||2004 Re-introduced in 2006 ||2006 ||Full rights purchased from partner Elan in 2013.{{cite web |url = http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Treating-MS/Medications/Tysabri-%C2%AE |title = Tysabri |publisher = National MS Society }} |- |} == Pipeline == Biogen has focused its R&D efforts on the discovery and development of treatments for patients with high unmet medical needs in the areas of neurology, hematology and immunology. Investigational MS medicines: * Daclizumab High-Yield Process (DAC HYP): is being developed as a potential once-monthly subcutaneous injection in the treatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). DAC HYP is being developed in collaboration with [[Abbvie]], Inc. In June 2014, the companies announced positive top-line results from the Phase III DECIDE clinical trial, where DAC HYP demonstrated superiority over interferon beta-1a in annualized relapse rate.{{cite web |url = http://www.fiercebiotech.com/story/once-monthly-ms-drug-biogen-idec-abbvie-clears-phase-iii-hurdle/2014-06-16 |title = Once-monthly MS drug from Biogen Idec, AbbVie clears Phase III hurdle |publisher = Fierce Biotech |accessdate=2013-04-08 }} * Anti-LINGO-1 (BIIB033) ([[Opicinumab]]): is the first candidate being investigated for its potential to remyelinate and repair neurons damaged by MS, currently in Phase 2 trials.{{cite web |url = http://multiple-sclerosis-research.blogspot.com/2013/05/lingo-promising-remyelination-target-in.html |title = Lingo: a promising remyelination target in MS |publisher = Multiple Sclerosis Research |accessdate=2014-06-16 }} Biogen has several candidates in Phase 1 and 2 clinical trials in neurodegenerative and immunological diseases including MS, Alzheimer's disease, neuropathic pain, spinal muscular atrophy and lupus nephritis: * Phase 2a: anti-LINGO-1 molecule ([[Opicinumab]]) in acute optic neuritis * Phase 2b: anti-TWEAK monoclonal antibody in lupus nephritis * Phase 2a: STX-100 in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis * Phase 2: Neublastin for neuropathic pain in 2013 * Phase 3:{{cite web |url = http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/868438 |title = Aducanumab Reduces Amyloid Plaques in Early Alzheimer's |publisher = PRIME }} BIIB037 ([[Aducanumab]]), Biogen's first clinical study in Alzheimer's disease * Phase 1/2: BIIB067 (ISIS-SOD1Rx) for [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]], in collaboration with Ionis Biogen also has several development agreements in place with Ionis Pharmaceuticals to collaborate to leverage antisense technology in advancing the treatment of neurological disorders.{{cite web |url = http://www.fiercebiotech.com/special-reports/top-20-biotech-licensing-deals-h1-2012/isis-pharmaceuticals-and-biogen-idec |title = Isis Pharmaceuticals and Biogen Idec |publisher = Fierce Biotech }} In February 2012, Biogen formalized a joint venture with [[Samsung]], creating Samsung Bioepis. This joint venture brings Biogen's expertise and capabilities in protein engineering, cell line development, and recombinant biologics manufacturing to position the joint venture so Biogen can participate in the emerging market for biosimilars.{{cite web |url = http://www.businessweek.com/news/2013-11-12/biogen-sees-eloctate-fda-delay-pushing-market-entry-to-mid-2014 |title = Biogen Sees Eloctate FDA Delay Pushing Marketing to Mid-2014 |publisher = BusinessWeek |accessdate=2013-12-11 }} In early 2014, Biogen entered into an agreement with Eisai, Inc., to jointly develop and commercialize two of their candidates for Alzheimer's disease, which have the potential to reduce Aβ plaques that form in the brains of patients, as well as to slow the formation of new plaques, potentially improving symptoms and suppressing disease progression.{{cite web |url = http://www.fiercebiotech.com/special-reports/top-20-biotech-licensing-deals-h1-2012/isis-pharmaceuticals-and-biogen-idec |title = Isis Pharmaceuticals and Biogen Idec |publisher = Fierce Biotech }} Biogen also has since 2015 an agreement with AGTC for the development of gene therapy for ophthalmologic diseases such as X-linked retinoschisis (XLRS) and X-linked Retinitis pigmentosa (XLRP), and up to three other genetic diseases. To this aim, Biogen paid AGTC $124 million, including an equity investment of $30 millions, and up to 1,1 billion in future milestones.Biogen Offers Up To $1 Billion for AGTC’s Ophthalmology Gene Therapy, Xconomy Boston, David Holley, July 2nd, 2015, http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2015/07/02/biogen-offers-up-to-1-billion-for-agtcs-ophthalmology-gene-therapy/ ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.biogen.com Official website] {{Finance links | name = Biogen | symbol = BIIB | sec_cik = BIIB | yahoo = BIIB | google = BIIB }} {{NASDAQ-100}} {{Pharmaceutical companies of the United States}} {{Portal bar|Companies}} {{coord|42|21|58.3|N|71|5|13.2|W|display=title}} [[Category:Companies based in Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies of the United States]] [[Category:National Medal of Technology recipients]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies of the United States]] [[Category:Pharmaceutical companies established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Orphan drug companies]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:1978 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies established in 1978]] [[Category:Spinal muscular atrophy]] [[Category:Companies formed by merger]] [[Category:Health care companies based in Massachusetts]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox alpine ski racer |name = Bojan Križaj |image = |disciplines = [[Giant Slalom skiing|Giant slalom]], [[Slalom skiing|Slalom]],
[[Alpine skiing combined|Combined]] |club = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|01|03|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Kranj]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]] |height = |wcdebut = 10 December 1976 |retired = 26 March 1988 |website = |olympicteams = |olympicmedals = 0 |olympicgolds = 0 |worldsteams = |worldsmedals = 1 |worldsgolds = 0 |wcseasons = 12 |wcwins = 8 |wcpodiums = 33 |wcoveralls = 0 |wctitles = 1 |medals = {{MedalSport|Men's [[alpine skiing]]}} {{MedalCountry|{{YUG}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[Alpine World Ski Championships 1982|1982 Schladming]]|Slalom}} }} '''Bojan Križaj''' ({{audio|Sl-Bojan Križaj.oga|listen}}) (born 3 January 1957) is a Slovenian, back then Yugoslavian, former [[alpine skier]]. During his international career he competed for the then-existing [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]. He competed at three Winter Olympics.{{cite Sports-Reference |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/kr/bojan-krizaj-1.html |title=Bojan Križaj Olympic Results |accessdate=19 March 2018}} ==Career== Križaj, born in [[Kranj]], was a member of a well known [[Tržič]] ski family so he started skiing at the age of 3. In the season 1976/77 he received the first World Cup point, qualified among the 15 best [[Slalom skiing|slalom]] runners and later during that season in [[Madonna di Campiglio]] he hit his first top 3 podium. On 20 January 1980 he achieved the first [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] World Cup victory in [[Wengen, Switzerland|Wengen]], [[Switzerland]] and later he won seven more times, thus still being Yugoslavia's and Slovenia's most successful male alpine skier to date. At [[1980 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]], [[United States|U.S.]], he reached the fourth place in [[giant slalom]], missing the bronze medal by only two hundredths of second. Four years later he took the [[Olympic Oath|athlete's oath]] at the opening ceremony for [[Sarajevo]]'s [[1984 Winter Olympics]]. He caused a stir when he spoke the oath not in [[Croatian or Serbian]] but in [[Slovene language|Slovene]]. Despite great expectations of the Yugoslav audience he finished ninth in [[giant slalom]], much less than expected. Križaj should also have competed at [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in [[Calgary|Calgary, Alberta]], [[Canada]], but he got injured a few days before the event. His most successful World Championship was in 1982 in [[Schladming]], [[Austria]] where he received the silver medal in [[Slalom skiing|slalom]]. His most successful World Cup season was 1986/87 when he received the small crystal globe for the season's best slalom runner (that was the only men's crystal globe of that season not won by [[Pirmin Zurbriggen]]). Beside that he was the second in World Cup slalom standings in the 1979/80 and 1985/86 seasons and third in the 1980/81 season. His best position in overall World Cup standings was the 4th place in 1979/80. He concluded his career in 1988 at the race in [[Saalbach-Hinterglemm|Saalbach]], [[Austria]] where he stepped off the skis right at the end of the track and walked into the finish area. Since his skiing retirement he worked in many fields, including as importer of Austrian brand beer and adviser for ski products in [[Elan Line|Elan]] company. In March 2006 he became Head of Slovenian Ski Pool. ==World Cup results== ===Season titles=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Season ! Discipline |- | rowspan="1"|'''[[1987 Alpine Skiing World Cup|1987]]''' || [[Slalom skiing|Slalom]] |} ===Season standings=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" ! Season ! Age ! Overall ! {{Infobox person | name = Brian Cassin | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Brian Jude Cassin | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1967|09}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Irish | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Trinity College, Dublin]] | occupation = CEO, [[Experian]] | known for = | boards = [[Experian]]
[[Sainsbury's]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | relations = | website = }} '''Brian Jude Cassin''' (born September 1967) is an Irish businessman, the CEO of [[Experian]]. Cassin was born in September 1967.{{cite web|title=EXPERIAN FINANCE PLC|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/00146575/officers|website=companieshouse.gov.uk|accessdate=14 April 2016}} He is a graduate of [[Trinity College, Dublin]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=884858&privcapId=8122148|publisher=bloomberg.com|title=Stocks - Bloomberg|accessdate=10 September 2016}} He is the CEO of [[Experian]], board member since 16 July 2014, when he was the CFO, and a non-executive director of [[Sainsbury's]].{{cite web|title=BRIAN CASSIN|url=https://www.experianplc.com/about-us/board-and-senior-management/board-of-directors/brian-cassin/|website=experianplc.com|accessdate=14 April 2016}} Cassin previously held senior roles at Baring Brothers International and the [[London Stock Exchange]] and was a managing director of the investment bank [[Greenhill & Co.]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/irish-boss-of-experian-earns-20pc-of-predecessors-pay-in-first-year-31300618.html|title=Irish boss of Experian earns 20pc of predecessor's pay in first year - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2018-07-13|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cassin, Brian}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Dublin]] {{Ireland-business-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} {{OSM Location map | lat=51.455 <!--latitude as a +/- decimal. + = north of the equator--> | lon=-2.593 <!--longitude as a +/- decimal. +=east of the Greenwich meridian--> | zoom=13 <!--(1=whole world, 18=a street)--> | width =400 <!-- width and height of the frame. numeric input - do not add px --> | height =400 | caption =Map of central Bristol showing some enterprise zone locations (in red) | mark-lat =51.44976 <!-- lat and lon location for the marker --> | mark-lon =-2.58116 | label =Temple Meads | label-pos =right | label-offset-y=-5
<!--Values to the unnumbered label are only used for that label. Label1 acts as a 'master marker', and parameter values set for it are passed on to all the other numbered markers, unless individually set--> | mark-lat1 =51.44636 | mark-lon1 =-2.57829 | label1 =Bristol Arena | label-pos1 =left
| mark-lat2 =51.44902 | mark-lon2 =-2.57833 | label2 =Temple Quarter Campus | label-pos2 =right | label-offset-x2=-10 | label-offset-y2=10
| mark-lat3 =51.45140 | mark-lon3 =-2.58204 | label3 =Temple Quay | label-pos3 =right | label-offset-y3=-5
| mark-lat4 =51.44417 | mark-lon4 =-2.56528 | label4 =Paintworks | label-pos4 =left
|minimap = file |mini-file=England south location map.svg |mini-width=120 |mini-height=72 |minipog-x=58 |minipog-y=30 |scalemark =170 }} '''Bristol Temple Quarter Enterprise Zone''' is an [[enterprise zone]] in [[Bristol]], England, focused on creative, high-tech and low-carbon industries. Covering an area of {{convert|70|ha}}, it is based around [[Bristol Temple Meads railway station]], which is being redeveloped by [[Network Rail]]. It also contains the area around the existing [[Temple Quay]] development, and the Silverthorne Lane and Avon Riverside areas. It includes the site of the planned [[Bristol Arena]],<ref name=BP1>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/enterprising-idea-radically-new-approach/story-19489241-detail/story.html |title=An enterprising idea with a radically new approach |newspaper=[[Bristol Post]] |date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=18 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095845/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/enterprising-idea-radically-new-approach/story-19489241-detail/story.html |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and the site of the [[University of Bristol]]'s planned Temple Quarter Campus.
==Establishment== The creation of the zone was announced by Chancellor [[George Osborne]] in the Budget of March 2011,<ref name=BP2>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bristol-enterprise-zone-looks-momentum/story-20963315-detail/story.html |title=Bristol enterprise zone looks to keep up the momentum |newspaper=Bristol Post |date=16 April 2014 |accessdate=18 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402100649/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bristol-enterprise-zone-looks-momentum/story-20963315-detail/story.html |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and it was launched in 2012.<ref name=BP1/> The zone offers streamlined [[planning permission|planning controls]] and reduced [[business rates in England and Wales|business rates]]. Rates generated by the zone are channelled to five other areas in the region,<ref name=BBC2>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-13681651 |title=Land near Temple Meads named as Bristol enterprise zone |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> designated Enterprise Areas. These are [[Avonmouth]] (focusing on manufacturing and distribution), [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] (media and publishing), [[Emersons Green]] including [[Bristol and Bath Science Park]], [[Filton]] (high-tech) and [[Weston-super-Mare]] (business services). Development of the enterprise zone is coordinated by West of England Local Enterprise Partnership, [[Bristol City Council]], the [[Homes and Communities Agency]] (HCA) and Network Rail.<ref name=BP1/>
==Station and surrounds== Network Rail is redeveloping the station,<ref name=BP1/> in conjunction with its [[21st-century modernisation of the Great Western Main Line|electrification of the Great Western line]] which will cut the journey time from Temple Meads to [[London Paddington station]] to 80 minutes.<ref name=BP2/> Station Approach Road will be turned into a public square and the station's main entrance moved to the north side of the station.<ref name=BBC6>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-20328428 |title=Bristol Temple Meads station to get £100m investment |work=BBC News Online |date=14 November 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> In January 2015, the council announced changes to the layout of the roads around the station, with the removal of Temple Circus roundabout and provision of better routes for pedestrians and cyclists.<ref name=BBC5>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-30775854 |title=Bristol's Temple Gate layout change planned in £21m revamp |work=BBC News Online |date=12 January 2015 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref>
Across Station Approach from the station,<ref name=BP2/> the Temple Gate redevelopment by TCN UK is a creative and digital campus for [[small and medium-sized enterprises]]. Redeveloped buildings include Bristol and Exeter House and Temple Studios. The latter opened in 2013.<ref name=BP1/>
[[File:2014 at Bristol Temple Meads Engine Shed - lounge area.JPG|thumb|Engine Shed's lounge area]] Engine Shed is a new use for part of the Old Station, [[Brunel]]'s original building, in partnership with the [[University of Bristol]].<ref name=BP1/> Opened in December 2013,<ref name=Thompson1>{{cite web |url=http://www.southwestbusiness.co.uk/sectors/construction-and-commercial-property/09072015134027-how-to-build-engine-shed-2-as-a-home-for-high-tech-high-growth-businesses-in-bristol-in-the-face-of-risk-averse-property-investors/ |title=How to build Engine Shed 2 as a home for high-tech high-growth businesses in Bristol in the face of risk averse property investors |last=Thompson |first=Gavin |work=SouthWestBusiness |date=9 July 2015 |accessdate=11 December 2016 }}</ref> it hosts [[business incubators]], including [[SETsquared]] and WebStart Bristol, which support a cluster of hi-tech [[startup companies]].<ref name=G1>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2014/feb/10/bristol-tech-industries |title=Why tech industries are thriving in the south-west of England |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=10 February 2014 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> Engine Shed leases its office space to the incubators, who in turn sub-let space on more flexible terms to the companies, which are selected for their high growth potential, and high expected benefits for the regional economy.<ref name=Thompson1/> In December 2015, with the building fully occupied, additional space was made available in the form of Boxworks, which was rapidly constructed by ForwardSpace next to Engine Shed using 20 [[intermodal container|shipping containers]]. This was intended to be a temporary solution until an Engine Shed 2 is built.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.southwestbusiness.co.uk/regions/bristol/03122015103916-bristol-should-be-planning-to-build-engine-shed-3-and-4--says-property-expert/ |title=Bristol should be planning to build Engine Shed 3 and 4, says property expert |last=Thompson |first=Gavin |work=SouthWestBusiness |date=3 December 2015 |accessdate=11 December 2016 }}</ref> Public consultation for Engine Shed 2 took place in November 2016.<ref name=Clensy>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/engine-shed-marks-third-anniversary-with-public-consultation-for-engine-shed-2/story-29946048-detail/story.html |title=Engine Shed marks third anniversary with public consultation for Engine Shed 2 |last=Clensy |first=David |newspaper=Bristol Post |date=30 November 2016 |accessdate=5 December 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Temple Quarter Campus== In November 2016, the University of Bristol announced that it will build a £300 million Temple Quarter Campus for c. 5,000 students, directly to the east of the station. It will replace an empty [[sorting office]] building, formerly operated by [[Royal Mail]] but derelict since 1997. The campus, which will include a new [[business school]], digital research facilities and a student village, is expected to open in 2021. It will also host Engine Shed 2.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/bristol-university-to-take-over-royal-mail-sorting-offices-by-temple-meads-for-new-300m-campus/story-29935566-detail/story.html |newspaper=Bristol Post |title=Bristol University to take over old sorting office by Temple Meads for new £300m campus |last=Yong |first=Michael |date=29 November 2016 |accessdate=29 November 2016 }}</ref>
==Arena Island== {{Main|Bristol Arena}} The zone's biggest development site, sometimes known as 'Arena Island', is south of the station and across the [[River Avon, Bristol|River Avon]].<ref name=BBC3>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-23087542 |title=Temple Quarter Enterprise Zone bridge plan wins £11m |work=BBC News Online |date=27 June 2013 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> Formerly occupied by the [[Bristol Bath Road depot]], the site was acquired by the Homes and Communities Agency.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-16210090 |title=Temple Meads diesel depot to be used by creative groups |work=BBC News Online |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> In February 2014 Bristol Council agreed the financing of the [[Bristol Arena|arena]], which including funding provided by the West of England Local Enterprise Partnership totals £91 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-26236200 |title=Bristol City Council agrees to help fund £91m Arena |publisher=BBC News Online |date=19 February 2014 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> The winner of the competition to design the arena, the architectural firm [[Populous (company)|Populous]], was announced in March 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Winning-design-chosen-Bristol-s-90million-arena/story-26187828-detail/story.html |title=Winning design chosen for Bristol's £90 million arena |newspaper=Bristol Post |date=17 March 2015 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> In the same month, the HCA gave the arena site to Bristol City Council.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-32076706 |title=Council handed land for Bristol Arena by the government |work=BBC News Online |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2013 the HCA agreed to fund an £11 million road bridge over the river, to link Cattle Market Road to the site of the planned arena.<ref name=BBC3/> Construction of the {{convert|63|m|adj=on}} bridge took place from March to September 2015. It has lanes for cars, bicycles and pedestrians.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-34115495 |title=Bristol Arena Island bridge finished |work=BBC News Online |date=2 September 2015 |accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref> In March 2016, the bridge was named Brock's Bridge, after William Brock (1830–1907), a local builder and entrepreneur.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-35829350 |title=Bristol bridge named after Victorian builder William Brock |work=BBC News Online |date=17 March 2016 |accessdate=22 April 2016 }}</ref>
==Temple Quay== {{Main|Temple Quay}} [[File:Valentines Bridge in the Temple Quarter Enterprise Zone.JPG|thumb|Valentine Bridge in Temple Quay]] Temple Quay is an area of [[mixed-use development]] on a site to the northwest of the station,<ref name=Oatley>{{cite book |chapter='Out of touch, out of place, out of time': a valediction for Bristol Development Corporation |last1=Oatley |first1=Nick |last2=May |first2=Andrew |title=British Urban Policy: An Evaluation of the Urban Development Corporations |editor1-last=Imrie |editor1-first=Rob |editor2-last=Thomas |editor2-first=Huw |publisher=Sage Publications |location=London |year=1999 |isbn= |pages=190-6 }}</ref> where the station's [[goods yard]] was formerly located.<ref>{{cite book |title=Brunel's Bristol Temple Meads |last=Binding |first=John |publisher=Oxford Publishing |location=Hersham |year=2001 |isbn=0-86093-563-9 |pages=112–3 }}</ref> The development project was initiated in 1989 by [[Bristol Development Corporation]], who originally called it Quay Point. In 1995, the corporation transferred its rights on the site to [[English Partnerships]], and development started in 1998.<ref name=Oatley/> The developer was Castlemore Securities.<ref name=pwc>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/bristol-building-work-completed/story-11238409-detail/story.html |title=Bristol building work 'will be completed' |newspaper=[[Bristol Post]] |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2016 }}</ref> By 2002, the development south of [[Bristol Floating Harbour]] was largely complete and a new phase was started on the other side of the harbour, called Temple Quay North.<ref>{{Cite book | last=Foyle | first=Andrew | title=Pevsner Architectural Guide, Bristol | publisher=Yale University Press | location=New Haven | year=2009 | page=267 | isbn=978-0-300-10442-4 }}</ref> Castlemore went into [[administration (law)|administration]] in 2009, but development continued in the hands of the administrator, [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]].<ref name=pwc/>
In 2015, [[Entrepreneurial Spark]], a UK-wide business incubator network, opened a hub on the top floor of the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]]'s Trinity Quay building in Temple Quay North.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.southwestbusiness.co.uk/regions/bristol/e-sparks---where-fledgling-firms-find-their-wings--29112016141331/ |title=E-sparks - where fledgling firms find their wings |last=Clensy |first=David |newspaper=South West Business |date=29 November 2016 |accessdate=6 January 2017 }}</ref> Managed by [[NatWest]], the hub provides free space, facilities and guidance for startups.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.southwestbusiness.co.uk/regions/bristol/16092015124228-entrepreneurial-spark-hub-by-natwest-launches-in-bristol-/ |title=Entrepreneurial Spark hub by NatWest launches in Bristol |last=Yong |first=Michael |newspaper=South West Business |date=16 September 2015 |accessdate=6 January 2017 }}</ref>
==Avon Riverside== The Avon Riverside area extends along the [[A4 road (England)|A4 Bath Road]], and Bristol's so-called 'media mile', as far as the site of Paintworks, an existing mixed-use development by Verve.<ref name=BP3>{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Bristol-s-booming-tech-sector-leading-way-ndash/story-24159127-detail/story.html |title=Bristol's booming tech sector is leading the way – now commercial property market needs to catch up |newspaper=Bristol Post |date=5 November 2014 |accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> Phase III of Paintworks will be the development of a 'creative skills hub' for digital and media businesses, in partnership with Creative Skillset.<ref name=BP1/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.bristoltemplequarter.com/ Official website]
{{coord|51.446|N|2.578|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Economy of Bristol]] [[Category:Bristol Harbourside]] [[Category:Mixed-use developments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:High-technology business districts in the United Kingdom]]

revision.comment: Filled in 4 bare reference(s) with [[:en:WP:REFILL|reFill]] () remove deprecated infobox parameter
revision.text:
{{advertisement|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = The Business Times | type = Daily business newspaper | format = [[Broadsheet]] on weekdays, compact weekend edition | editor = Wong Wei Kong | oclc = 70880991 | website = {{URL|businesstimes.com.sg}} | owner = [[Singapore Press Holdings]] }} '''''The Business Times''''' is an English-language financial daily based in [[Singapore]] currently owned by [[Singapore Press Holdings]] (SPH). It is currently the only daily newspaper in [[Singapore]] that focuses on business and financial news. Its average daily circulation (print and digital editions combined) as of August 2016 was 36,900, according to SPH. <ref> [url=http://www.sph.com.sg/our-businesses/newspapers/the-business-times-the-business-times-weekend/ SPH].</ref> ''The Business Times'' is published as a broadsheet on weekdays, with a weekend edition that is published as a compact-sized paper. On October 8, 2016, The Business Times revamped its weekend edition, featuring its own luxury [[lifestyle magazine]]. The main newspaper section for the weekend was also rebooted.
==History==
BT started as a supplement that was distributed three times a week with [[The Straits Times]]. On Oct 1, 1976, [http://www.businesstimes.com.sg The Business Times] became a newspaper in its own right. In June 1995, BT became the first English-language newspaper in [[Asia]] to go online. By 2000, [https://web.archive.org/web/20141006095605/http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/ BT's website] was offering news updates throughout the day. In February 2012, BT launched a sister site [http://www.btinvest.com.sg/ BTInvest], a portal focused on finance and investment. Over the course of 2012 and 2013, BT also rolled out mobile apps, for the [https://itunes.apple.com/sg/app/business-times-for-iphone/id531275824?mt=8 iPhone], [https://itunes.apple.com/sg/app/business-times-for-ipad/id531283825?mt=8 iPad] and [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ps.bt&hl=en Android smartphones].
In October 2014, BT simultaneously refreshed its newspaper, website, tablet and smartphone apps.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businesstimes.com.sg/consumer/refreshed-paper-refreshed-newsroom|title=Refreshed paper, refreshed newsroom|first=Teh Shi|last=Ning|publisher=}}</ref> One big change - applied to both its print and digital products - was in how it organises the news. Previously organised by geographical markets, BT's news is now categorised by industry sectors. The paper said that this was to underline its sharpened focus on business. Sections include: Companies & Markets, Real Estate, Banking & Finance, Energy & Commodities, Technology, Consumer, Transport and Government & Economy. Another important change for the [https://web.archive.org/web/20141006095605/http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/ BT website] was the shift to [[responsive web design]], which ensures that the site is readable and easy to navigate on any screen. Other key changes include an emphasis on [[visual journalism]] and [[data-driven journalism]], and the introduction of three new [[blogs]] on the website.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/20141014113048-39458673-five-things-to-know-about-the-new-business-times|title=Five Things to Know About the NEW Business Times|date=14 October 2014|publisher=}}</ref> The 2014 redesign also won BT an Award of Excellence from the [http://www.snd.org/ Society of News Design] in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snd.org/competitions/database/?d=1&contest=&ID=42367|title=Search Competition Database|date=16 August 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
==Editors== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Name !! Title<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businesstimes.com.sg/content/about-us|title=About Us - THE BUSINESS TIMES|publisher=}}</ref> |- | Wong Wei Kong || Editor |- | Lee Su Shyan || Executive Editor |- | Edmund Loh || Night Editor |- | Dennis Chan || Deputy Night Editor |- | Lilian Ang || BT Inc Editor |- | Chen Huifen ||News Editor |- | Kenneth Lim || Deputy News Editor |- | Joyce Hooi || Deputy News Editor |- | Lee U-Wen || Deputy News Editor |- | Andrew Tan || Chief Sub-editor |- | Jaime Ee || Lifestyle Editor |- | Christopher Lim || Digital Editor |- | Lee Kim Siang || Deputy Digital Editor |- |- |}
==Magazines==
===Wealth=== Wealth is a magazine distributed with the Business Times. Targeted at high net worth individuals and highlights issues that are relevant to them in terms of their investments, wealth structuring, philanthropy and more. Genevieve Cua is the magazine's editor.
===The SME Magazine=== The SME Magazine is a bi-monthly magazine distributed with The Business Times, which deals with issues close to the hearts of Singapore's SMEs and entrepreneurs. Vivien Shiao is the magazine's editor.
=== BTLuxe Christmas === BTLuxe Christmas is an annual publication dedicated to the lifestyle needs of our high net worth readership, covering the fields of fashion, art, design, food, travel and more.
==Business awards== The Business Times organises the following annual business awards events in conjunction with various partners.
===[http://www.sbawards.com.sg/ The Singapore Business Awards]=== This was launched in 1985, with the Businessman of the Year Award. In 1986, the Enterprise Award was introduced to recognise small and medium-sized enterprises. In 1990, the Outstanding Manager Award was introduced to recognise professional managers. This was renamed the Outstanding Chief Executive of the Year Award in 1995. In 2005, the Outstanding Chief/Senior Executive (Overseas) Award was introduced, to recognise Singaporean CEOs working abroad. Winners of the four awards, known collectively as the Singapore Business Awards, are decided by a panel of judges drawn from the business sector, official agencies and academia.
===[http://www.scawards.com.sg/ The Singapore Corporate Awards]=== This recognises excellence in corporate governance, with five awards: Best Managed Board, Best Chief Executive Officer, Best Chief Financial Officer Award, Best Investor Relations Award and Best Annual Report Award.
===[http://www.enterprise50.org/ The Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards]=== This was launched in 1995 to recognise local, privately held companies who have contributed to economic development in Singapore and abroad.
===[http://www.eeaward.com/ The Emerging Enterprise Award]=== This was first launched in 2008 to recognise outstanding small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. Winners receives prizes to support their growth and development, such as interest-free loans and professional services and training programmes
==Community==
===[http://baf.sg/?page_id=17 The Business Times Budding Artists Fund]=== In 2005, BT adopted the Budding Artists' Fund, an initiative of The Old Parliament House (2002-2014). The fund was started with a conviction that no child should be denied the opportunity to pursue a training in the arts due to a lack of financial resources. Beneficiaries of BT BAF are trained primarily at [https://www.facebook.com/littleartsacademy The Little Arts Academy (LAA)], which was set up in November 2008, to provide equal opportunity for all of them to be fully engaged in the arts.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/ The Business Times website] *{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/*/http://business-times.asia1.com.sg|title=Business Times}} *[http://www.btinvest.com.sg BTInvest] *[http://www.facebook.com/thebusinesstimes The Business Times on Facebook] *[https://twitter.com/BusinessTimes The Business Times on Twitter] *[http://www.linkedin.com/company/the-business-times The Business Times on LinkedIn] *[http://plus.google.com/b/100689337808190739965/+BusinessTimesSgBT/posts The Business Times on Google+] *[http://newslink.asiaone.com/user/Login.action SPH Newslink for The Business Times archives] *[http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Default.aspx?source=digitised NewspaperSG - digital archive of Singapore newspapers]
{{Singapore Press Holdings}}

revision.comment: Added links; see also Third-party doctrine
revision.text:
{{Evidence law}} The '''business records exception''' to the [[Hearsay in United States law|U.S. hearsay rule]] is based on Rule 803(6) of the [[Federal Rules of Evidence]] (FRE). It is sometimes referred to as the '''business entry rule'''.
==Scope of exception== [[Business records]], for the purposes of the exception, are any writings or records of acts, events, conditions, opinions, or diagnosis, made at or near the time by, or from information transmitted by, a person with knowledge are admissible if kept in the regular course of business and if it was the regular course of business to make that record, unless the source of information or circumstances of preparation indicate a lack of trustworthiness.
Business is used in Rule 803(6) to mean any business, institution, association, [[profession]], or occupation, regardless of whether or not it is conducted for [[Profit (economics)|profit]]. Therefore, such records could conceivably include those of [[Religion|religious]] and [[charitable organization]]s, [[hospital]]s, [[school]]s, and even criminal organizations.<ref name="federalevidence.com">http://federalevidence.com/rules-of-evidence#Rule803</ref>
==Rationale== The basic rationale for the exception is that employees are under a duty to be accurate in observing, reporting, and recording business facts. The underlying belief is that special reliability is provided by the regularity with which the records are made and kept, as well as the incentive of employees to keep accurate records (under threat of [[Termination of employment|termination]] or other penalty). The exception functions to allow the record to substitute for the in-court testimony of the employees, but it can only substitute for what the employee could testify about. The availability of the [[declarant]] (the employee whose testimony is being replaced by the record) is immaterial for the purposes of this exception.
===Reliability of the statements in the record=== It must be apparent to the judge that the record was made in the regular course of business, i.e., that it was customary practice to make such an entry and that the entrant had a duty to record it (either by law or by the terms of his employment). The record must have been made at or near the time of the act, event, or transaction at issue. Furthermore, the record must consist of matters either within the personal knowledge of the entrant or within the personal knowledge of someone with a duty to transmit the information to the entrant.
This last point was contested in the case of ''Johnson v. Lutz'', 253 N.Y. 124, 170 N.E. 517 (1930), which held that a business record is admissible only when it is made by an employee about information, obtained by him, from an informant who himself was under a business duty to impart that information. ''Johnson'' dealt specifically with the admissibility of [[police report]]s, and set a limitation on the use of such reports in court. Even though the police officer was under a duty to properly record the statements of an [[informant]], the informant himself was under no duty to report the events correctly, and therefore the informant's statement was still inadmissible hearsay.
===Limitation on admissibility of records prepared for litigation=== In the case of ''[[Palmer v. Hoffman]]'', {{ussc|318|109|1943}}, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled that an accident report created by a [[railroad]] company which was prepared in anticipation of a [[lawsuit]] by the victim was inadmissible, because it was not prepared in the regular course of business. Railroad travel, and not litigation, was the primary business of the railroad, and therefore the report was not considered sufficiently reliable to be admitted into evidence.
==Lack of record as evidence== FRE 803(7) states the negative counterpart of the business records exception: the use of the ''lack of a record'' to prove that a transaction or occurrence had not taken place, if it was the regular practice of the business to record such events if they had actually occurred.<ref name="federalevidence.com"/>
==Other types of business records== Under FRE 803(17), market reports and [[Financial quote|quotations]], directories, and other published compilations are considered generally admissible if they are generally used and relied upon by the public or by persons in particular occupations. Such information is considered admissible separate and apart from privately made business records described above.
==See also== *[[Third-party doctrine]], on Fourth Amendment protection for business records
==References== {{Reflist}}
*BarBri Evidence Review outline, 2006, pp. 76–79. *Fisher, George. ''Evidence''. pp. 484–491. Foundation Press, 2002. {{ISBN|1-58778-176-X}}
==External links== *[http://law.jrank.org/pages/4953/Business-Record-Exception.html Entry from Thomson West Legal Encyclopedia, courtesy of Jrank]
[[Category:Hearsay]] [[Category:United States law]] [[Category:Business documents]] [[Category:Records management]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Christopher Karl Mellon | honorific_suffix = | image = Christopher Mellon.jpg | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = Christopher Karl Mellon | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|10|02}} | birth_place = [[Topeka, Kansas]] | baptised = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | burial_place = | burial_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | citizenship = | education = [[Yale University]], [[Colby College]] | alma_mater = | occupation = Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence, Senate Intelligence Committee | years_active = 1985-2004 | era = | employer = | organization = [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], [[United States Senate]] | relatives = Judge [[Thomas Mellon]], [[Andrew Mellon]], [[Matthew Mellon]] | family = [[Mellon family]] | callsign = | awards = The Secretary of Defense Meritorious Public Service Award,
The Secretary of Defense Outstanding Public Service Award,
The National Reconnaissance Office Gold Medal,
The Defense Intelligence Agency Director’s Medal,
The National Imagery and Mapping Agency Medallion for Excellence | website = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | ethnicity = }} '''Christopher Karl Mellon''' (born October 2, 1957){{Cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QJJY-DKYY|title=United States Public Records|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}, is the former United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence and later for Security and Information Operations. He is also a writer and businessman. He is a member of the [[Mellon family]], and the son of Karl N. Mellon, the great-grandson of [[Gulf Oil]] co-founder [[William Larimer Mellon]]."[http://www.post-gazette.com/downloads/20070701Mellon_tree_fix.pdf Mellons* in Pittsburgh]," ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''Fitzpatrick, Dan, "[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07182/798280-28.stm Mellon family's legacy lives on]," ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' ==Biography== Christopher Mellon is a descendant of [[Thomas Mellon]], founder of [[Mellon Bank]]. He received his Bachelor of Arts Degree in Economics from [[Colby College]] in 1980. He earned his master's degree from [[Yale University]] in [[International relations|International Relations]], with a concentration in [[finance]] and management in 1984. Mellon served for 12 years in a variety of positions on [[Capitol Hill]], including nearly 10 years as a professional staff member as a Staff Director of the [[Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]].{{Citation Needed|date=May 2017}} He was the [[Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense]] for Intelligence from November 1999 until Jan 2002. From June 1998 through November 1999, Mr. Mellon served as the [[United States Assistant Secretary of Defense|Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense]] for Security and Information Operations. In that capacity, he was responsible for policy and programmatic oversight of information assurance, [[critical infrastructure protection]], security, [[counterintelligence]], and information operations strategy and integration. Mellon went to the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] as a member of [[William Cohen|Secretary Cohen's]] transition team on January 2, 1997. Following the transition, Mellon was appointed as the Coordinator for Advanced Concepts and Program Integration, Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, concentrating on [[encryption]] and information assurance issues.{{Citation Needed|date=May 2017}} From November 1997 to June 1998, he served as the Special Assistant to the Secretary of Defense for Intelligence Policy, providing advice on a range of intelligence issues. Before entering the [[private sector]], Mellon returned to [[United States Capitol|Capitol Hill]] where he served as the Minority Staff Director of the Senate Intelligence Committee for Senator [[John D. Rockefeller, IV]] from 2002-2004.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041114004031/http://www.law.harvard.edu/academics/graduate/hcia/panelist_bio_65.php|title=Christopher Mellon|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}} Mr. Mellon is currently a private equity investor and an advisor and shareholder for 'To the Stars Academy of Arts and Sciences'.{{cite news |last=Mellon |first=Christopher |title=The military keeps encountering UFOs. Why doesn’t the Pentagon care? - We have no idea what’s behind these weird incidents because we’re not investigating. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/the-military-keeps-encountering-ufos-why-doesnt-the-pentagon-care/2018/03/09/242c125c-22ee-11e8-94da-ebf9d112159c_story.html |date=March 9, 2018 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=March 14, 2018 }}{{Cite news|url=https://dpo.tothestarsacademy.com/|title=To The Stars Academy|date=October 10, 2017 |work=To the Stars|access-date=March 14, 2018 }} == Notes == 1. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041114004031/http://www.law.harvard.edu/academics/graduate/hcia/panelist_bio_65.php |date=November 14, 2004 |title="Panelist" }}, ''[[Harvard Law School]]'' == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mellon, Christopher}} [[Category:American intelligence analysts]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Mellon family]] [[Category:American people of Scotch-Irish descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Colby College alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:People from Topeka, Kansas]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Politician |honorific-prefix = |name = Colin Craig |honorific-suffix = |image = File:Colin Craig.JPG |imagesize = 225px |caption = |order = 1st Leader of the [[Conservative Party of New Zealand|Conservative Party]] |deputy = [[Christine Rankin]] |term_start = 3 August 2011 |term_end = June 2015 |successor = [[Leighton Baker]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1968|1|8}}<ref name="about">{{cite web |url= http://www.votecolincraig.co.nz/aboutcolin.php |title=Vote Colin Craig: About Colin Craig |work=votecolincraig.co.nz |year=2010 |accessdate=26 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713091031/http://www.votecolincraig.co.nz/aboutcolin.php |archivedate=13 July 2010}}</ref> |birth_place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand |spouse = Helen Craig |children = 1<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/9603791/Smacking-law-is-stupid-Colin-Craig|title=Smacking law is stupid: Colin Craig|first=Stacey|last=Kirk|date=13 January 2014|publisher=|accessdate=2 June 2017|via=Stuff.co.nz}}</ref> |occupation = Businessman and politician |religion = Christian (raised [[Baptists|Baptist]])<ref name="trad">{{cite news |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Conservative-party-leader-happy-being-traditional/tabid/419/articleID/220943/Default.aspx |title=Conservative party leader happy being 'traditional' |first=Kim |last=Chisnall |work=3 News |date= 3 August 2011 |accessdate=26 November 2011}}</ref> |party = [[Conservative Party of New Zealand|Conservative]] |website = {{URL|votecolincraig.co.nz/}} |signature = }} '''Colin Craig''' (born 8 January 1968)<ref name="about"/> is a New Zealand businessman who was the founding leader of the [[Conservative Party of New Zealand]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.conservativeparty.org.nz/index.php?page=people_page |title=People|publisher=Conservative Party of New Zealand |accessdate=14 September 2011}}</ref> Craig is a millionaire who owns companies that manage high-rise buildings.<ref name="NZH-07-31-11">{{cite news |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=31 July 2011 |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10741939 |title=Dreams of Act's demise |first=David |last=Fisher }}</ref> His current company manages about $1.3 billion of assets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nzcpr.com/guest243.htm |title=Making referendum count |publisher=New Zealand Centre for Political Research |accessdate=20 September 2011}}</ref> He is against [[same-sex marriage]], foreign ownership of land and housing and [[Crimes (Substituted Section 59) Amendment Act 2007|"anti-smacking" legislation]]. On 19 June 2015, Craig resigned as leader of the Conservative Party following allegations of inappropriate behaviour surrounding the party's former press secretary Rachel MacGregor (to which he admitted later at a second press conference on 22 June 2015 with his wife)<ref>https://www.kiwiblog.co.nz/2015/06/craig_admits_to_inappropriate_behaviour.html</ref><ref>http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11710453</ref> and tensions with the party's governing board. Craig has since admitted to inappropriate conduct with MacGregor but has denied charges of sexual harassment a claim being challenged in the courts by several people including Craig himself.<ref name="nzherald.co.nz">http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11879730</ref><ref name="NZHerald 19 June 2015">{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Audrey|title=Colin Craig could face the chop after TV antics|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11467479|accessdate=19 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=19 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="One News 21 June 2015">{{cite news|author=<!-- staff reporter -->|title=Colin Craig claims evidence of allegations withheld by Conservative Party|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/colin-craig-claims-evidence-allegations-withheld-conservative-party-6342837|accessdate=21 June 2015|agency=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]|date=21 June 2015}}</ref> On 27 June, Colin Craig was formally suspended from the Conservative Party.<ref name="NZH 27 June 2015">{{cite news|last1=Theunissen|first1=Matthew|title=Colin Craig's membership suspended|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11472161|accessdate=27 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=27 June 2015}}</ref> Since then, his suspension has been invalidated which would enable Craig to contest the Conservative Party's leadership.<ref name="NZ Herald 5 July 2015">{{cite web | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=11476110 | accessdate=2015-07-06 | title=Conservative Party battle draws to a close | date=July 5, 2015 | publisher=''The New Zealand Herald'', Auckland, New Zealand}}</ref><ref name="Stuff.co.nz 7 July 2015">{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Colin Craig asks forgiveness and puts his political future to a ballot|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/70035019/colin-craig-asks-forgiveness-and-puts-his-political-future-to-a-ballot|accessdate=10 July 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=7 July 1025}}</ref> On 16 November 2015, Craig announced that he would not be contesting the Conservative Party leadership in lieu of a police investigation against him over his Party's spending during the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]].<ref name="NZH 16 Nov 2015">{{cite news|last1=Davidson|first1=Isaac|title=Colin Craig won't seek re-election|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11546300|accessdate=17 November 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=16 November 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Born in [[Auckland]] and raised in the suburb of [[Howick, New Zealand|Howick]],<ref name="about"/> Craig attended Macleans College<ref>Interview with Audrey Young "[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11171609]"</ref> and graduated from the [[University of Auckland]] with [[Bachelor of Commerce]] and Bachelor of Arts degrees before completing post-graduate study at [[Massey University]].<ref name="about"/> He has one daughter with his wife Helen.<ref name="about"/> His father, Ross Craig, served as a [[Rodney District]] councillor until 2010.<ref name=confident/>
Craig is a [[conservative]] Christian brought up in the [[Baptist]] denomination, but does not attend a church.<ref>Andrea Vance (12 May 2012). "[http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/comment/6905832/The-curious-case-of-Colin-Craig The curious case of Colin Craig]". ''Dominion Post''.</ref> As of June 2014, he is resident in [[Fairview Heights, Auckland|Fairview Heights]] on Auckland's North Shore.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elections.org.nz/parties-candidates/registered-political-parties/party-donations/donations-exceeding-30000/returns |title= Returns of party donations exceeding $30,000 |publisher= Electoral Commission |accessdate= 16 August 2014}}</ref>
==Views== Craig has stated he is not sure that "legislating morality" works well.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Conservatives-open-to-both-Labour-and-National/tabid/419/articleID/231969/Default.aspx |title=Conservatives open to both Labour and National |first=Chris |last=Whitworth |work=3 News |date= 7 November 2011|accessdate=26 November 2011}}</ref> However, he has described legalisation of same-sex marriage as "social engineering",<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/6904721/Legalising-gay-marriage-social-engineering-Craig |title=Craig slams gay marriage|first=Andrea |last=Vance |work=stuff.co.nz |date=11 May 2012 |accessdate=15 May 2012}}</ref> and is also opposed to gay adoption,<ref name="dompost-curious-case-of-craig">{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/comment/6905832/The-curious-case-of-Colin-Craig|accessdate=30 August 2014|publisher=Dominion Post|first=Andrea|last=Vance|title=The curious case of Colin Craig}}</ref> adolescent access to abortion,<ref name="dompost-curious-case-of-craig" /> and [[voluntary euthanasia]] or assisted suicide.<ref name="dompost-curious-case-of-craig" /> In May 2012, Craig described New Zealand's young men and women as "the most promiscuous in the world" based upon surveys such as [[David P. Schmitt]]'s International Sexuality Description Project research statistics<ref>{{cite web |url= http://podcast.radionz.co.nz/mnr/mnr-20120509-0835-conservatives_reject_birth_control_for_beneficiary-048.mp3 |title=Conservatives reject birth control for beneficiaries |work=radionz.co.nz |date=9 May 2012 |accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref> and anecdotal evidence from New Zealand gynaecologists,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10737380 |title=NZ Women Promiscuous – Doctor |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> a statement which was dismissed by Prime Minister [[John Key]]<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/6888733/Key-slams-Conservative-promiscuous-claim |title=Key slams Conservative promiscuous claim |first= Kate|last=Chapman|work=stuff.co.nz |date = 9 May 2012|accessdate=15 May 2012}}</ref> and other political leaders like [[Tariana Turia]] and [[Winston Peters]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10804591 |title=No proof to promiscuity claim – PM |first=Paul |last=Harper |first2 = Audrey |last2 = Young |work=nzherald.co.nz |date = 9 May 2012|accessdate=15 May 2012}}</ref>
Following a series of child poverty items on current affairs show [[Campbell Live]] and a fundraising effort from the show to raise money for school lunches,<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Campbell-Lives-Lunchbox-Day/tabid/817/articleID/270147/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ | title= Campbell Live's Lunchbox Day | date=21 September 2012}}</ref> Craig said children sent to school without lunch should go without. Instead, their parents should be charged the "cost of rectifying their bad behaviour".<ref name="3news.co.nz">{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/No-free-lunches-for-hungry-kids-says-Colin-Craig/tabid/1607/articleID/273895/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ | title= 'No free lunches' for hungry kids, says Colin Craig | date=24 October 2012}}</ref>
In September 2012, Craig had 20,000 leaflets delivered to residents in the [[Helensville (New Zealand electorate)|Helensville]] electorate, claiming locals had told him Helensville MP and Prime Minister [[John Key]] was "too gay" to be their representative in Parliament.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Key-shrugs-off-gay-comments/tabid/1607/articleID/267700/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ | title= Key shrugs off gay comments| date=2 September 2012}}</ref>
In April 2013 Craig sided with controversial Danish politician [[Marie Krarup]] after she called a traditional [[Māori people|Maori]] greeting "grotesque".<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Powhiri-grotesque--Danish-politician/tabid/1607/articleID/293475/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Powhiri 'grotesque' – Danish politician| date=8 April 2013}}</ref> Craig said no visitors should have to face a "bare-bottomed native making threatening gestures" if they didn't want to.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Bare-bottom-welcomes-%60should-be-optional/tabid/1607/articleID/293441/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Bare bottom welcomes 'should be optional'| date=8 April 2013}}</ref>
Following the legalisation of same sex marriage in April 2013,<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Gay-marriage-bill-will-save-lives/tabid/1607/articleID/294712/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ | title= Gay marriage bill will 'save lives'| date=18 April 2013}}</ref> Craig said "the day of reckoning" would come, that it was a "failure of democracy"<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Gay-marriage-vote-a-failure-of-democracy---Craig/tabid/1607/articleID/294731/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Gay marriage 'a failure of democracy' – Craig| date=18 April 2013}}</ref> and that "[it] was not a vote of the people of New Zealand," adding "If it had been, the answer would have been no."<ref>Gay marriage opponents licking wounds http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/politics/8566153/Gay-marriage-opponents-licking-wounds</ref>
Craig has been known to take offence at satirical articles directed at him, including a piece on the satirical website ''[[The Civilian]]'', which he said published a story designed "to make him look ridiculous".
