He threatened to sue the site unless they published a retraction and paid him $500.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Colin-Craig-threatens-satirical-website/tabid/1607/articleID/295333/Default.aspx | work=3 News NZ | title= Colin Craig threatens satirical website| date=23 April 2013}}</ref> Craig withdrew the threat the following day.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Colin-Craig-abandons-defamation-suit/tabid/1607/articleID/295366/Default.aspx |work=3 News NZ |title= Colin Craig abandons defamation suit| date=24 April 2013}}</ref>
In November 2013 Craig said humans were not to blame for [[climate change]], instead pointing to sunspots and "the circulation of planets".<ref>[http://www.3news.co.nz/VIDEO-Who-is-Colin-Craig/tabid/1607/articleID/321351/Default.aspx#.UoVj7-HIhnE VIDEO: Who is Colin Craig?]. ''3 News NZ''. 15 November 2013.</ref>
==Political career==
===March for Democracy=== Craig first emerged as a conservative activist in 2009<ref name="NZH-07-31-11"/> when he organised and funded a "march for democracy" to protest government decisions not to adhere to three [[Referendums in New Zealand|citizen's initiated referenda]]:<ref name=nzhmarch>{{cite news | url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/democracy/news/article.cfm?c_id=171&objectid=10605777 | title=Smacking law march aims to be big | newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=28 October 2009 |accessdate=29 September 2011 | first=Simon | last=Collins}}</ref>
# the [[New Zealand MP reduction referendum, 1999]], on a proposed reduction in the number of members of parliament (1999 – 81% in favour) # the [[New Zealand justice referendum, 1999]], re sundry suggested changes to the justice system (1999 – 92% in favour) # the [[New Zealand citizens-initiated referendum, 2009|2009 referendum]] concerning the repeal of the [[Crimes (Substituted Section 59) Amendment Act 2007|2007 amendment of the Crimes Act]], the so-called "anti-smacking" law, which removed parental corporal punishment as a defense in criminal assault cases (2009 – 87% in favour).
He spent $450,000 organising the march,<ref name=nzhmarch/> and it attracted 5,000 participants.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10610750 |title=One arrest as thousands join 'March for Democracy' |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=21 November 2009 |agency=[[NZPA]]}}</ref> In 2010, Craig contested the [[Auckland mayoral election, 2010|Auckland Mayoral election]], finishing third<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10655119 |title=Organiser of democracy march joins mayoral race |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=29 June 2010 |accessdate=29 September 2011 |first=Bernard |last=Orsman}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/local-elections-2010/4215301/Len-Brown-beats-John-Banks-in-super-race |title=Len Brown beats John Banks in super-race |newspaper=Stuff |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=29 September 2011}}</ref> with 42,598 votes behind [[Len Brown]], mayor of Manukau City (237,487 votes) and [[John Banks (New Zealand politician)|John Banks]] (New Zealand politician and former mayor of Auckland – 171,542 votes), but ahead of incumbent North Shore City mayor [[Andrew Williams (New Zealand politician)|Andrew Williams]] (3,813 votes).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/AboutCouncil/HowCouncilWorks/Elections/Pages/Finalresults-Mayor.aspx |title = Mayor (1) final results |work = Auckland Council |publisher = Auckland Council |accessdate = 22 December 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120111063126/http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/AboutCouncil/HowCouncilWorks/Elections/Pages/Finalresults-Mayor.aspx |archivedate = 11 January 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
===Conservative Party leadership=== In 2011 Craig announced the formation of the [[Conservative Party of New Zealand]].<ref name="NZH-08-04-11">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10742803 |title=Craig no threat to Banks in Epsom, says Brash |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=29 September 2011 |first1=Hayden |last1=Donnell |first2=Adam |last2=Bennett}}</ref><ref name="NZH-08-03-11">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10742678 |title=Colin Craig announces new Conservative Party |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=29 September 2011}}</ref> The party contested the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011 general election]] on a variety of issues, including the introduction of binding referenda, reducing the number of members of parliament while increasing the electoral term by one year, [[Law and order (politics)|law and order]] reform (including work for prisoners), a repeal of the New Zealand [[emissions trading scheme]], the protection of state assets (notably the [[New Zealand foreshore and seabed controversy|foreshore and seabed]]), and [[fiscal conservatism]]. In September 2011, he announced he would stand in the [[Rodney (New Zealand electorate)|Rodney]] electorate for the 2011 general election.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10752761 |title=Colin Craig won't go up against John Banks |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=19 September 2011 |date=19 September 2011}}</ref>
After pre-election polling in this electorate, Craig claimed to have 47% support while the [[National Party of New Zealand|National Party]] candidate Mark Mitchell had 36.3%.<ref name=confident>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10752948 |title=Conservative leader confident he can take Rodney from Nats |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=20 September 2011 |first1=Matthew |last1=Backhouse |first2=Adam |last2=Bennett |date=20 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radiolive.co.nz/Colin-Craig-to-stand-in-Rodney/tabid/506/articleID/23214/Default.aspx |title=Colin Craig to stand in Rodney |publisher=Radio Live |accessdate=19 September 2011}}</ref> Prime Minister and National Party leader John Key said that the Conservative Party faced a "massive hurdle" to get a seat in Parliament.<ref>{{cite news |author=New Zealand Press Association |date=8 August 2011 |title=Key won't rule out working with new party}}</ref> According to preliminary election results, Mitchell won the seat with 52.6% of the vote, and Colin Craig came second with 21.4% of the vote. The Conservative Party also gained 2.76% of the vote nationwide, the fifth-largest share of any party and more than four of the parties that actually won seats, but this was insufficient for any Conservatives to enter Parliament because of the 5% of the party vote or one electorate seat required by the [[Mixed-member proportional representation|mixed-member proportional voting system]] operating in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.org.nz|title=Electoral Commission|website=Electoral Commission|accessdate=2 June 2017}}</ref>{{better source|date=June 2015}}
Since the Conservative party's conception, Craig has donated $4 million. He is one of the party's two major donors besides [[Waikato]] businessman Laurence Day.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Kirk | first1=Stacey | last2=Easton | first2=Paul|title=Colin Craig resigns ahead of Conservative Party leadership vote|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/69544937/colin-craig-resigns-ahead-of-conservative-party-leadership-vote|accessdate=21 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=19 June 2015}}</ref> Craig stood as a candidate in the [[East Coast Bays (New Zealand electorate)|East Coast Bays electorate]] in the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]] but failed to win the electorate. His party received 4.1% of the vote; less than 5% of the voting threshold which denied them a seat in the New Zealand Parliament.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Bennett | first1 = Adam | date = 22 June 2014 | title = Colin Craig to contest McCully for East Coast Bays seat | url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11279380 | newspaper = The New Zealand Herald | location = Auckland | publisher = APN New Zealand Limited | issn = 1170-0777 | accessdate = 18 July 2014 | quote = Conservative Party leader Colin Craig has confirmed he will contest Murray McCully's East Coast Bays seat in the September election.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sincock|first1=Taylor|title=Craig: Next election will be the one|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/politics/craig-next-election-will-be-the-one-2014092023#axzz3dfMEfax4|accessdate=21 June 2015|agency=[[3 News]]|date=20 September 2014}}</ref> On 18 September 2014, the Conservative Party's press secretary Rachel MacGregor resigned, citing his alleged manipulative behaviour. When questioned by the media, Craig denied the allegations and offered to discuss the issue with MacGregor following the 2014 general election.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dougan|first1=Patrick|title=Colin Craig's press secretary quits, reportedly calls him a 'manipulative man'|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11326951|accessdate=21 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=18 September 2014}}</ref>
In February 2014, the-then [[Green Party of Aotearoa New Zealand|Green Party]] co-leader [[Russel Norman]] alleged that Colin Craig held misogynistic and homophobic attitudes during a speech at the Big Gay Out event in Auckland. Norman's comments prompted Craig to file a defamation suit and to demand that Norman issue an apology. In response, Norman and the Green Party announced that they would contest the lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|title=Colin Craig to limit his defamation claim|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11213649|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=4 March 2015}}</ref> On 10 October 2014, following the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]], both parties settled the lawsuit out of court and agreed to bear their own legal expenses.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Simon|title=Colin Craig drops defamation case against Russel Norman|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/colin-craig-drops-defamation-case-against-russel-norman-2014101015#axzz3iY3Nkw7R|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=3 News|date=10 October 2014}}</ref>
===2015 leadership dispute=== In June 2015, Colin Craig drew criticism from elements of the Conservative Party when he participated in a [[sauna]] interview hosted by [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]] reporter [[David Farrier]], which they felt badly reflected on Craig's public image. The interview was part of the television channel's new Sauna Session current affairs series.<ref name="NZHerald 19 June 2015" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Farrier|first1=David|title=The Sauna Session That May Bring Down Colin Craig|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/tvshows/newsworthy/sauna-session-with-colin-craig-2015060823#axzz3dYJsninl|accessdate=19 June 2015|agency=[[3 News]]|date=9 June 2015}}</ref> Following sexual harassment allegations that were published on the right-wing blogger [[Cameron Slater]]'s blog Whale Oil, Craig resigned as party leader on 19 June 2015 and also agreed to "facilitate a review" of the leadership. Craig was also criticised by elements of the Conservative Party for postponing a leadership vote at a scheduled board meeting that month.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Conservative faction to block Colin Craig's return as leader|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/69559312/conservative-faction-to-block-colin-craigs-return-as-leader|accessdate=19 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=19 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Slater|first1=Cameron|title=Exclusive: The poem Colin Craig doesn't want you to see|url=http://www.whaleoil.co.nz/2015/06/exclusive-the-poem-colin-craig-doesnt-want-you-to-see/|website=Whale oil|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
On 20 June 2015, Colin Craig announced that he was not ruling out a return to the Conservative Party's leadership if he found sufficient support from the Party's members. He also threatened to sue several media outlets over allegations that he had paid off his former secretary MacGregor over a complaint of sexual harassment to the [[Human Rights Commission (New Zealand)|New Zealand Human Rights Commission]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Watkins|first1=Tracey|title=Colin Craig off to lawyers, would consider a Conservative Party comeback|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/69567213/colin-craig-off-to-lawyers-would-consider-a-conservative-party-comeback|accessdate=21 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=21 June 2015}}</ref> On 21 June, the ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' reported that Craig had settled a "financial dispute" with MacGregor for around NZ$16,000 to $17,000 approximately eight weeks earlier.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bilbey|first1=Lynley|title=Colin Craig entangled in money dispute|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11468628|accessdate=21 June 2015|newspaper=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=21 July 2015}}</ref> The television channel [[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] also reported that there was a serious falling-out between Craig and several Conservative board members. One board member, John Stringer, has accused Craig of lying to the board and other inappropriate behaviour. In response, Craig has denied these allegations and threatened to take action against Stringer for speaking to the media.<ref name="One News 21 June 2015" />
During the press conference held on 22 June 2015, Craig admitted that he had acted inappropriately towards his press secretary Rachel MacGregor but denied any charges of sexual harassment. In response, MacGregor accused the former Conservative leader for breaching a confidentiality agreement the pair had reached under Human Rights Commission mediation and disputed his version of the events. Craig's wife Helen Craig also announced that she was standing by her husband and characterised the charges against him as "false allegations."<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig admits 'inappropriate' conduct|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/69601091/colin-craig-admits-inappropriate-conduct|accessdate=22 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=22 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='Factual inaccuracies' - former press secretary speaks out after Colin Craig denies allegations|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/factual-inaccuracies-former-press-secretary-speaks-after-colin-craig-denies-allegations-6343893|accessdate=22 June 2015|agency=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]|date=22 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|title=Colin Craig is trying to frame me as a mistress|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11469290|accessdate=23 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=22 June 2015}}</ref> Both Craig and MacGregor have also denied that they were involved in a romantic relationship.<ref>{{cite news|title='Had you fallen in love with Rachel MacGregor?' - Colin Craig pushed over ex-press secretary|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/had-you-fallen-in-love-rachel-macgregor-colin-craig-pushed-over-ex-press-secretary-6344120|accessdate=23 June 2015|agency=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]|date=23 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Colin Craig's ex-aide denies sexual relationship|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/69601091/colin-craigs-exaide-denies-sexual-relationship|accessdate=23 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=23 June 2015}}</ref> Both Craig and MacGregor have also indicated that they would support the lifting of the confidentiality agreement in order to allay uncertainty and speculation.<ref name="Stuff 23 June 2015">{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Colin Craig expects 'face-palm moments' ahead|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/69626551/colin-craig-expect-facepalm-moments-ahead|accessdate=23 June 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=23 June 2015}}</ref>
According to the ''Herald'', several board members of the Conservative Party including John Stringer, [[Christine Rankin]], and Laurence Day have indicated support for a change of leadership. A board meeting has been scheduled for 27 June 2015 and Day has also called for Craig to be expelled from the party.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|title=Calls for Colin Craig's party membership to be cancelled|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11469194|accessdate=22 June 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=22 June 2015}}</ref> Following the resignation of six Conservative Party board members, Craig indicated that a new board and a new leader would later be elected by the Party over the weekend. Craig has not ruled out contesting the leadership poll. It is currently unclear whether the dissolution of the board would favor Craig or any other contender for the Conservative Party's leadership.<ref name="Stuff 23 June 2015" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Davison|first=Isaac|title=More board members quit Conservative Party|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11469835}}</ref>
On 27 June 2015, Colin Craig was formally suspended from the Conservative Party by the party's newly appointed board which consisted of John Stringer and four newly appointed members. Four of the five board members with the exception of Stringer voted to suspend the former Conservative leader's membership. The conference took place in a hotel room at the Heartland Hotel near [[Auckland International Airport]].<ref name="NZH 27 June 2015" /> According to One News, Craig has since challenged the legality of Stringer and the board's actions; claiming that Stringer had been suspended from the Party. He has also not ruled out contesting the Conservative Party's leadership. Craig's remarks have been dismissed by Stringer, who has become the Party's interim leader.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig has Conservative Party membership suspended|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/colin-craig-has-conservative-party-membership-suspended-6347983|accessdate=27 June 2015|publisher=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]]|date=27 June 2015}}</ref>
On 5 July 2015, John Stringer resigned his positions as chairman and board member to preserve the neutrality of the second Board so he and Craig could resolve their differences in court separately. According to the ''New Zealand Herald'', a statement by former chairman Brian Dobbs that Stringer had been suspended meant that the decision by the interim board to suspend Colin Craig's membership was invalid.<ref name="NZ Herald 5 July 2015" /> It transpired that the "suspension" of Stringer was nothing more than a phone call by Dobbs to Nathaniel Heslop (who had already resigned) and Stringer was never notified of any hearing or meeting being the only other Board member still active. Dobbs then resigned hours later with Stringer not being notified he was 'suspended" until a week later which was ignored. Documents later emerged that Craig had threatened Dobbs with personal liabilities of the party debts and letters flowed from Craig's lawyers to Dobbs. On 7 July, Craig also sent a personal letter to Conservative Party members to apologize for his behaviour and to gauge whether he had sufficient support to return to the Party's leadership.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz 7 July 2015" /> On 29 July 2015, Colin Craig announced that he was going to sue several opponents including Conservative Party member John Stringer, the right wing blogger [[Cameron Slater]] and [[New Zealand Taxpayers' Union]]'s president Jordan Williams for alleged defamation. In addition, Craig also circulated a booklet, entitled "Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas", which he claimed outlined a "campaign of defamatory lies" against him.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Corazon|last2=Davison|first2=Isaac|title=Colin Craig sues 'dirty politics brigade'|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11488774|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=29 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |last=Craig |first=Colin |date=2015 |title=Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas |url=http://votecolincraig.co.nz/documents/Dirty%20Politics.pdf |location=Auckland |publisher=Colin and Helen Craig |agency= |access-date=2015-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925161400/http://votecolincraig.co.nz/documents/Dirty%20Politics.pdf |archivedate=25 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 2 August 2015, Craig also announced his intention to contest the Auckland mayoral election in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Day|first1=Simon|title=Colin Craig could run for Auckland Mayor|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/70746613/colin-craig-could-run-for-auckland-mayor|accessdate=11 August 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=2 August 2015}}</ref>
On 10 August 2015, John Stringer lodged a complaint against Colin Craig with the [[New Zealand Police]], alleging that the later had exceeded his allocated election fund legal limit by NZ$2,000 when contesting the East Coast Bays electorate in 2014. In addition, Stringer criticized Craig's management of the Conservative Party's 2014 election campaign.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hutching|first1=Chris|title=Stringer reveals allegations he has taken to the police|url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/stringer-reveals-allegations-he-has-taken-police-ch-176899|accessdate=11 August 2015|publisher=''[[National Business Review]]''|date=9 August 2015}}</ref> The following day, Stringer submitted a dossier of documents to both the Police and the [[Electoral Commission (New Zealand)|Electoral Commission]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Peter|last2=Robson|first2=Sarah|title=Colin Craig documents given to police|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/colin-craig-documents-given-to-police-2015081115#axzz3iY3Nkw7R|accessdate=11 August 2015|agency=3 News|date=11 August 2015}}</ref> On 14 August 2015, Jordan Williams served proceedings in defamation against Colin Craig and several Conservative Party officials in response to Craig's statements at the July press conference and in the circular ''Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Nicholas|title=Legal action taken against Colin Craig|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11497297|accessdate=16 August 2015|publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]''|date=14 August 2015}}</ref> On September 11, 2015, Colin Craig filed a defamation suit against the Party's former chairman, John Stringer. Stringer has indicated that he would contest these charges in court.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig files defamation suit|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/283990/colin-craig-files-defamation-suit|accessdate=11 October 2015|publisher=Radio New Zealand News|date=11 September 2015}}</ref>
On 7 November 2015, Colin Craig was outed as the anonymous "Mr X" who posed as a party whistleblower that was interviewed in the "Dirty Politics" booklet delivered earlier in July. Despite acknowledging that he had fabricated the interview by posing as the interviewee, he defended his actions on the grounds that "talking about himself" in the third person was a common literary tool. He also stood by his assertions in the "Dirty Politics" booklet and vowed to continue his involvement in the Conservative Party.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Marika|title=Ex-Conservative leader Colin Craig outed as Mr X|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/73727758/exconservative-leader-colin-craig-outed-as-mr-x|accessdate=8 November 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|publisher=''[[The Sunday Star-Times]]''|date=7 November 2015}}</ref> On 16 November, Craig announced that he would not contest the Conservative Party's leadership in lieu of a police investigation over his Party's spending during the 2014 general election. However, he also indicated that he would contest the 2017 general elections if he was cleared and if the Party wanted him back.<ref name="NZH 16 Nov 2015" /> On 24 November, it was reported that Craig had demanded that the blogger Cameron Slater pay him NZ$15,000 as compensation for reproducing a poem written for his former press secretary Rachel MacGregor on his blog Whale Oil.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirk|first1=Stacey|title=Colin Craig claims $15,000 from Whale Oil blogger Cameron Slater for publication of 'Two of Me' poem|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/74343529/colin-craig-claims-15000-from-whale-oil-blogger-cameron-slater-for-publication-of-two-of-me-poem|accessdate=25 November 2015|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=24 November 2015}}</ref>
==Post-leadership== On 19 January 2016, Colin Craig donated NZ$36,000 to the Conservative Party. Despite his lack of involvement with the leadership, he stated that he and his wife still wanted to support the Party financially.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sachdeva|first1=Sam|title=Colin Craig donates $36,000 to Conservative Party after resigning as leader|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/76001561/colin-craig-donates-36000-to-conservative-party-after-resigning-as-leader|accessdate=3 February 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=19 February 2016}}</ref> On 1 March 2016, it was reported that former Conservative board member John Stringer had dropped his defamation suit against Craig and would seek legal advice to ensure that his statement of defence complied with court rules for defamation cases.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Van Breynen|first1=Martin|title=John Stringer dumps claim against Colin Craig in Christchurch defamation action|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/77468166/John-Stringer-dumps-claim-against-Colin-Craig-in-Christchurch-defamation-action|accessdate=11 April 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=2 March 2016}}</ref> In early April 2016, Craig tabled legal papers seeking more than $NZ13,000 in legal damages from blogger [[Cameron Slater]] for publishing his romantic poem ''The Two of Me'' relating to the former Conservative press secretary Rachel MacGregor on his blog Whale Oil the previous year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Poet, songwriter, and politician: Colin Craig sues Slater for publishing his poem|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/78466989/poet-songwriter-and-politician-colin-craig-sues-slater-for-publishing-his-poem|accessdate=11 April 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|publisher=''[[The Sunday Star-Times]]''|date=3 April 2016}}</ref>
In April 2016, the High Court ruled that the telecommunications company [[Vodafone]] could not disclose private email correspondence between Craig and former party member John Stringer, who welcomed the decision. Craig also agreed to pay Vodafone's legal bills.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Garrick|first1=Gia|title=Colin Craig ruled against in landmark decision to halt private email disclosure|url=http://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/news/national/colin-craig-ruled-against-in-landmark-decision-to-halt-private-email-disclosure/|accessdate=6 September 2016|publisher=Newstalk ZB|date=16 May 2016}}</ref>
===2016 Defamation lawsuit=== On 5 September 2016, Colin Craig appeared in the Auckland High Court to face a defamation lawsuit filed by Taxpayers' Union executive director Jordan Williams. Williams had filed the lawsuit after Craig alleged that Williams lied when he said that Craig had sexually harassed his former press secretary Rachel MacGregor. A jury of seven men and five women were selected for the trial, which is scheduled to take place for five weeks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig in court to defend defamation Action|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/312572/colin-craig-in-court-to-defend-defamation-case|accessdate=6 September 2016|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=5 September 2016}}</ref> On 6 September, Williams submitted text message correspondence between Craig and MacGregor as evidence of Craig's alleged sexual harassment. Williams has also alleged that Craig had breached a confidentiality agreement with McGregor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Sexual harassment allegations against Colin Craig detailed for first time|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/83944394/colin-craig-called-manipulative-during-defamation-case-against-him|accessdate=6 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=6 September 2016}}</ref>
On 7 September 2016, the former Conservative Party deputy [[Christine Rankin]] took the stand to testify in support of Williams' defamation suit. Rankin testified that revelations about Craig's alleged inappropriate relationship with MacGregor had led her to question Craig's suitability to lead the Party. That same day, Williams took the stand to read portions of Craig's poems to MacGregor. He also alleged that Craig's defence team had tried to link him to the ''[[Dirty Politics]]'' scandal by alleging that he had taken part in a smear campaign against the former head of the [[Serious Fraud Office (New Zealand)|Serious Fraud Office]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Colin Craig allegedly told Christine Rankin his secretary was 'mentally ill'|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/83989754/colin-craigs-alleged-love-letters-read-aloud-to-court|accessdate=8 September 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=7 September 2016}}</ref> On 8 September, the judge discharged a juror after he revealed that he had a connection to a witness who was scheduled to give evidence for Craig later in the trial. As a result, the trial would proceed with eleven jurors.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Colin Craig defamation trial: Juror discharged|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11705810|accessdate=8 September 2016|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=8 September 2016}}</ref>
On 8 September, Craig's lawyer Stephen Mills [[Queen's Council|QC]] cross-examined Williams, who admitted that he had never seen the actual "sex text" between Craig and MacGregor. He also presented correspondence between Craig and MacGregor and contended that their relationship was consensual. The following day, Mills continued his cross-examination of Williams and suggested that William's motives for releasing the letters and emails were link to an ulterior motive of removing Craig as Party leader. Williams admitted this was the case but asserted that Craig's alleged inappropriate relationship with MacGregor made him an unsuitable leader for a "Christian movement based on family values."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Colin Craig trial: all you need to know|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11706663|accessdate=11 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=9 September 2016}}</ref>
On 12 September, the former Conservative board member John Stringer alleged that Craig was involved romantically with other women besides Rachel MacGregor. He also denied that there was a "dirty politics" strategy against Craig and alleged that Crag had disciplines, harassed, and attacked members that had disagreed with him. In his testimony, Stringer also alleged that Craig had created a "cult-like culture of confidentiality within the Conservative Party."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hollingworth|first1=Adam|title=Colin Craig needed chaperone around MacGregor - Stringer|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/nznews/colin-craig-needed-chaperone-around-macgregor---stringer-2016091212|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Newshub|date=12 September 2016}}</ref> On 14 and 15 September, Craig's former press secretary Rachel MacGregor took the stand to testify about Craig's alleged sexual harassment during the three-year period she had spent working as his press secretary. In her testimony, MacGregor cited a disagreement about her pay rate as the final straw in her decision to resign as press secretary two days before the [[New Zealand general election, 2014|2014 general election]]. In addition, MacGregor admitted that Craig had once fallen asleep on her lap but denied singing Christian hymns to him during that incident.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Rachel MacGregor's text messages to Colin Craig read to court|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84256582/former-conservative-leader-colin-craig-under-huge-pressure-lawyers-say|accessdate=15 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=14 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Tahana|first1=Yvonne|title=Claims Colin Craig slept on Rachel MacGregor's lap while she sung him hymns|url=https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/claims-colin-craig-slept-rachel-macgregors-lap-while-she-sung-him-hymns|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=One News|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On 15 September, the former Auckland City councillor Aaron Bhatnagar testified in support of Williams. He dismissed Craig's claim that he had supplied the text correspondence between Craig and MacGregor to Williams as false allegations that had damaged his reputation.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Former councillor Aaron Bhatnagar: Colin Craig 'impugned my reputation'|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11710269|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=15 September 2016}}</ref>
On the afternoon of 15 September, Colin Craig and his lawyer Stephen Mills began presenting evidence for his defence after Jordan Williams and his team concluded their evidence.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Colin Craig to defend defamation case|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84281588/colin-craig-to-defend-defamation-case|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=15 September 2016}}</ref> On 16 September, Craig denied William's allegations that he had sexually harassed MacGregor and likened their relationship to that of siblings. Craig also testified that MacGregor had proposed to marry him but that he had turned her offer down because he was already married. In his testimony, he argued that his rejection of MacGregor's proposition had led her to resign as press secretary.<ref>{{cite news|title=Did she think I would leave my wife?|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11711164|accessdate=16 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=16 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fagans|first1=Josh|title=Colin Craig denies sexual harassment, explicit texts, but admits there was a kiss|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84324546/colin-craig-denies-sexual-harassment-explicit-texts-but-admits-there-was-a-kiss|accessdate=16 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=16 September 2016}}</ref>
On 19 September, Craig denied sending any sex text messages to Rachel McGregor but during cross-examination was unable to provide evidence supporting his claim. While hundreds of text messages from MacGregor's phone had been submitted as evidence, Craig's complete phone records have not been supplied to the court.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Craig can't prove he didn't send messages|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11712720|accessdate=20 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=19 September 2016}}</ref> The following day, Craig denied that he charged a 29.5% interest rate on MacGregor's loan in order to coerce her into dropping her sexual harassment claim against him. He maintained that he had imposed the interest rate after she had resigned because she had defaulted on a $19,000 loan.<ref name="RNZ 20 Sept">{{cite news|title=Craig charged 29.5% interest on loan to MacGregor|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/313766/craig-charged-29-point-5-percent-interest-on-loan-to-macgregor|accessdate=20 September 2016|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=20 September 2016}}</ref>
On 20 September, Craig's wife Helen Craig testified that MacGregor had privately called her to confess that she was having an emotional relationship with Craig. She added that MacGregor had admitted kissing Craig on the night of the 2011 general election. Helen also confirmed that she had forgiven her husband. Helen also testified that she and Craig had drawn up a set of " working rules" to govern his working relationship.<ref name="RNZ 20 Sept" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Court hears of 'relationship rules' between Rachel MacGregor and Colin Craig|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/84440974/macgregor-took-restraining-order-against-colin-craig-associate|accessdate=20 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=20 September 2016}}</ref> While Craig had admitted kissing McGregor, he denied undressing or having sexual intercouse with her.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Colin Craig on kiss with press secretary|url=http://m.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11713454|accessdate=20 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=20 September 2016}}</ref>
On 21 September, the investigative journalist [[Nicky Hager]] testified as part of Colin Craig's defense. In his testimony, he alleged that the information that had been released about Colin Craig on blogs like Cameron Slater's Whale Oil matched the patterns he had documented in his book ''[[Dirty Politics]]'', which had inspired Craig's pamphlet "Dirty Politics and Hidden Agendas".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Colin Craig defamation trial: Dirty Politics author Nicky Hager takes the stand|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11714115|accessdate=21 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=21 September 2016}}</ref> Brian Dobbs, the former chairman of the Conservative Party, also testified that he and several other board members had expressed their discomfort with Craig and MacGregor's relationship. He criticized Craig for proceeding with the a 2015 sauna interview with a journalist without consulting him first. Dobbs also disclosed that Williams had showed him a collection of love letters, poems, emails, and other correspondence between Craig and MacGregor in June 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig defamation trial: Nicky Hager gives evidence|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/313866/colin-craig-defamation-trial-hager-gives-evidence|accessdate=22 September 2016|publisher=Radio New Zealand|date=21 September 2016}}</ref>
On 22 September, former Conservative Party board member Laurence Day disputed Rachel MacGregor's claim that Colin Craig had sexually harassed her on the grounds that Williams had failed to present the incriminating alleged "sext" text message. He alleged that Williams was trying to use the sexual harassment allegations to turn the party board members against Craig. Meanwhile, [[Family First New Zealand|Family First]] director [[Bob McCoskrie]] described Williams' leak of the alleged sexual harassment allegations as part of an "organized campaign" to unseat Craig. Day and McCoskrie supported Craig's assertion that his relationship with MacGregor had been inappropriate but consensual. McCoskrie defended Craig's pamphlet as a response to the alleged "organized campaign" against Craig.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Former Conservative board member says a male secretary wouldn't have flattered Colin Craig|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84531305/family-first-director-bob-mccoskrie-says-colin-craigs-poetry-bad|accessdate=22 September 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=22 September 2016}}</ref>
On 23 September, several Conservative Party staff members testified in Craig's defense. Two staffers Bev Adair-Beets and Angela Storr alleged that MacGregor had tried to exploit her relationship with Craig and disputed her sexual harassment allegations. Another staffer Kevin Stitt vouched for the accuracy of the allegations presented in Craig's "Dirty Politics" pamphlet. The left-wing blogger [[Martyn "Bomber" Bradbury]] also alleged that Williams had embarked on what he described as a "political hit" job against the former Conservative leader. While on the stand, the plaintiff Williams disputed Craig's defense lawyer Stephen Mill's charge that he had used MacGregor for political gain.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leask|first1=Anna|title=Jordan Williams emotional and angry in court|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11715434|accessdate=23 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=23 September 2016}}</ref>
On 28 September, lawyers for both Jordan Williams and Colin Craig entered closing arguments. William's lawyer Peter Knight argued that the love letters and poems were proof that Williams had not been lying about Craig's alleged sexual harassment against MacGregor. In response, Craig's lawyer Stephen Mills asserted Craig had a right to defend himself through his "Dirty Politics" pamphlet. Mills also contended that Williams had broken MacGregor's trust by passing information on her relationship with Craig to other Conservative Party officials and [[Cameron Slater]]'s blog Whale Oil.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig trial: 'Jordan Williams wanted leader gone'|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11718475|accessdate=28 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=28 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig's lawyer makes final push to clear his name|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/politics/colin-craigs-lawyer-makes-final-push-to-clear-his-name-2016092811|accessdate=28 September 2016|publisher=Newshub|date=28 September 2016}}</ref>
On 30 September, after ten hours of deliberations, the jury unanimously found Craig guilty on two counts of defamation against Williams. Craig was ordered to pay $1.3 million in compensation and punitive damages to Williams. While Williams and his supporters including Cameron Slater have welcomed the decision, Craig's lawyers have announced that they would be appealing the verdict and challenging the size of the damages awarded.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wade|first1=Amelia|title=Colin Craig loses defamation case, ordered to pay $1.3m damages|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11715326|accessdate=30 September 2016|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=30 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Bath|first1=Brooke|last2=Dennett|first2=Kelly|title=Colin Craig ruled to have defamed Jordan Williams|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/84790345/colin-craig-jury-returns-in-defamation-case|accessdate=30 September 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=30 September 2016}}</ref>
=== Historic defamation damages award v Craig appealed === On 12 April 2017, High Court Justice Katz ruled that the compensation damages of $1.27 million constituted a "miscarriage of justice". The decision was welcomed by Colin Craig as a vindication of his assertion that he was responding to attacks on his character by Jordan Williams however the judge's decision related only to the amount of damages awarded to Williams against Craig by the jury not their verdict that Williams had been defamed by Craig which stood.
Justice Katz indicated that the two parties had until 26 April 2017 to consent to the High Court substituting its own award or setting aside the earlier verdict and ordering a retrial.<ref>{{cite news|title=$1.27m Colin Craig defamation damages ruled excessive|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/328704/$1-point-27m-colin-craig-defamation-damages-ruled-excessive|accessdate=13 April 2017|agency=Radio New Zealand|date=12 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Verdict may be set aside in Colin Craig v Jordan Williams defamation case|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11837168|accessdate=13 April 2017|publisher=New Zealand Herald|date=12 April 2017}}</ref> Mr Williams filed an appeal of the Katz decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://beta.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11847282|title=Jordan Williams appeals to try to avoid retrial in Colin Craig defamation case|website=NZ Herald|accessdate=2 June 2017}}</ref>
Colin Craig did not file an acceptance of this action by 26 April actioning an inevitable re-trial however Jordan Williams then filed an appeal of the judge's decision seeking the jury damages award in his favour stand. He released a press statement late April saying "Colin Craig argued that the jury's damages award was too high. The judge agreed but the High Court is only able to reset the damages if both parties agree...I don't want Rachel MacGregor or my mother or any other of my witnesses to have to go through it all again. The jury made clear findings. At every stage Mr Craig has wanted to stretch things out. We have no assurance he would not appeal after a new trial...So an appeal now could get to the key issues directly. It is the best way forward."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-nz/news/national/williams-appeals-in-craig-defamation-case/ar-BBAsUHO|title=Williams appeals in Craig defamation case|website=www.msn.com|accessdate=19 July 2017}}</ref>
=== Human Rights Review Tribunal record damages awarded against Craig === On 3 October, it was reported that the Human Rights Review Tribunal had, earlier in 2016, ordered Craig to pay Rachel MacGregor $128,780 in compensation for breaching the non-disclosure agreement with MacGregor by giving interviews about her. Because of the Williams defamation trial, the decision had been covered by blanket suppression until after the Williams v Craig verdict.
As of 2016, this amounts to the highest amount awarded by the Human Rights Review Tribunal. In addition, Craig paid MacGregor $100,000 relating to her legal costs.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Rachel MacGregor awarded $128k after Colin Craig breaches confidentiality|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/84900004/rachel-macgregor-awarded-damages-after-colin-craig-breached-confidentiality|accessdate=4 October 2016|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=3 October 2016}}</ref>
===Subsequent developments=== On 4 October, the Conservative Party's board chairman Leighton Baker (confirmed as new leader of the party on 24 January 2017<ref>Conservative Party website press release 24 Jan 2017</ref> confirmed that Colin Craig had resigned his membership and was not holding any positions in the party. However, Craig has not ruled out playing a role with the Conservatives after his legal problems were resolved.<ref>4 October 2016 Newshub and Paul Henry Breakfast</ref> On 6 December 2016, Craig won his bid for his upcoming defamation case against former Party official John Stringer to be heard before a judge rather than a jury<ref>Conservative Party doesn't want Colin Craig back|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/politics/conservative-party-doesnt-want-colin-craig-back-2016100407|accessdate=6 October 2016|publisher=Newshub|date=6 October 2016</ref> as with the Williams case which Craig lost with historic damages. The ''Craig v Stringer'' case had been scheduled to be heard in the Christchurch High Court before Justice Gendall for a three-week period on 6 March 2017 (''Craig v Stringer''). In late 2016 John Stringer succeeded before Justice Nation in having granted on application a Judicial Settlement Conference under r7:79 in Christchurch, at which on 30 January 2017 Craig and Stringer settled their differences and the case against Stringer was dropped. No money exchanged hands and the settlement was sealed by the court and will not be released.<ref>The Press/STUFF Adele Redmond 6:42pm 1 February 2017</ref>
On 6 December 2016, Judge Mary Beth Sharp of the Auckland District Court dismissed both of Craig's copyright lawsuits against Cameron Slater and Jordan Williams over the publication of Craig's poem ''Two of Me'' calling the claims "vexatious" and "improper" and a "deception perpetrated on the court".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dennett|first1=Kelly|title=Colin Craig's latest lawsuit thrown out; called vexatious|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/87263343/colin-craigs-latest-lawsuit-thrown-out-called-vexatious|accessdate=7 December 2016|publisher=Stuff.co.nz|date=7 December 2016}}</ref> On 6 April 2017, Colin Craig filed a $240,000 lawsuit against former employee Jacqueline Stiekema regarding defamatory statements she had allegedly made on a [[Facebook]] page and other defamatory publications she had made to a third person.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colin Craig suing again|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/new-zealand/2017/04/colin-craig-suing-again.html|accessdate=13 April 2017|agency=Newshub|date=6 April 2017}}</ref> On 29 March 2017 Associate Judge Bell transferred the application to strike out the case to the district court.<ref>High Court decisions. "[http://www.nzlii.org/nz/cases/NZHC/2017/614.html]"</ref>
===2017 defamation trials=== Craig and blogger Cameron Slater both sued each other for defamation following the 2014 election. The cases were held in May 2017 and Craig represented himself in the four week trial. The Judge reserved his decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/93193627/closing-submissions-heard-in-colin-craig-defamation-trial|title=Closing submissions heard in Colin Craig defamation trial|website=Stuff|accessdate=2 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Braunias |first1=Steve |title=Craig v Slater: The end of the affair |url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11868133 |accessdate=25 October 2018 |publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' |date=3 June 2017}}</ref>
8 May - 1 June 2017 the Craig v Slater (and Slater v Craig counterclaim) CIV2015-404-1923 was heard in the Auckland High Court before Justice Toogood. Slater was represented by Brian Henry and Craig represented himself. The trial went a week past its scheduled three weeks. Craig said the case came down to credibility and whom the judge believed was telling the truth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whaleoil.co.nz/2017/06/craig-v-slater-day-17-media-roundup/|title=Craig v Slater Day 17 (media roundup) – Whale Oil Beef Hooked - Whaleoil Media|date=1 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=19 July 2017}}</ref> Slater sued Craig for alleged defamatory statements in his booklet "Dirty Politics & Hidden Agendas" (2015) and Craig sued Slater for making alleged defamatory statements on his blog. These included that Craig: had sexually harassed Rachel MacGregor; lied about it; and covered it up after settling a sexual harassment hearing in the Human Rights Commission and then the Human Rights Review Tribunal; and that there was a "second woman".
It dramatically transpired during the trial that Slater had been rung by a barrister that he knew (and whose identity vocation and area of practice he had chosen to keep anonymous) was in fact working for Colin Craig. There was disagreement over phone calls on 24 and 25 June 2015 initiated by the barrister and allegedly by Mr Craig which left Slater with an inference the barrister (a sexual harassment specialist) was representing a "second victim" with whom "Craig was a factor".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whaleoil.co.nz/2017/06/craig-v-slater-final-media-roundup-now/|title=Craig v Slater final media roundup... for now – Whale Oil Beef Hooked - Whaleoil Media|date=2 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=19 July 2017}}</ref> However, neither the barrister nor Craig ever revealed the conflict of interest nor did Craig correct Slater's inference at any stage leading up to and during most of the trial (the "second woman" was a central factor in both the earlier ''Craig v Stringer'' and ''Williams v Craig'' proceedings based on that evidence). Craig instead chose to sue all three parties for this contention which he knew was false yet allowed Slater to infer without correction until the much later trial.
The judge reserved his decision on 1 June 2017 to be delivered "as quickly as possible."
The Slater trial was the second in a triumvirate of trials central to a cluster of ancillary proceedings involving Craig (in the District Court; in hearings; in tribunals; and with the police; the Privacy Commission and the Electoral Commission all based on independent complaints). The main three trials (all filed 2015) concern the so-called "Dirty Politics Brigade" (Jordan Williams; Cameron Slater; John Stringer) alleged in the Craig's booklet "Dirty Politics & Hidden Agendas (2015) named after the Hager book "Dirty Politics" (2014). The Williams trial concluded 30 September 2016; the Slater-Craig trials 1 June 2017; and Stringer v Craig & Others CIV2015-404-2524 is anticipated later in 2017 which will be the largest of the three. The latter has six defendants including Helen Craig but one of the defendants (a lawyer) settled with John Stringer in May 2016. Stringer and Craig also settled "Craig v Stringer" (CIV2015-409-0575) on 30 January 2017 in the Christchurch high court for zero an unrelated but parallel proceeding to the three main trials which largely concern the same issues and the same people.
On 9 June, it was reported that Colin Craig had filed a lawsuit against his former press secretary Rachel MacGregor. He was criticized by MacGregor, her advocate Ruth Money, and Jordan Williams for abusing the legal process.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Satherley|first1=Dan|title=Colin Craig sues ex-press secretary Rachel MacGregor|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/politics/2017/06/colin-craig-sues-ex-press-secretary-rachel-macgregor.html|accessdate=14 June 2017|publisher=Newshub|date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=King|first1=Helen|title=Rachel MacGregor please with Colin Craig to let her 'get on with my life'|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/93611318/rachel-macgregor-unaware-of-defamation-proceedings|accessdate=14 June 2017|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=12 June 2017}}</ref> On 20 June, MacGregor filed a counter-suit against her former employer for defamation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rachel MacGregor counter-sues Colin Craig for defamation|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/93899563/rachel-macgregor-countersues-colin-craig-for-defamation|accessdate=31 July 2017|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=20 June 2017}}</ref> On 31 July, Judge Garry Harrison dismissed Craig's lawsuit against the former employee Jacky Stiekema, who had previously worked as a trust accounts manager for his company Centurion Management.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holye|first1=Craig|title=Judge throws out Colin Craig's bid to sue former employee for defamation|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/95304867/judge-throws-out-colin-craigs-bid-to-sue-former-employee-for-defamation|accessdate=31 July 2017|agency=Stuff.co.nz|date=31 July 2017}}</ref>
===Second strike-out of Craig suit 1 September 2017===
On Friday 1 September 2017 Judge Harrison delivered a second strike-out of a Craig defamation suit.<ref>http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/338504/colin-craig-ordered-to-pay-17k-in-costs-to-woman-he-tried-to-sue</ref><ref>https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/95304867/judge-throws-out-colin-craigs-bid-to-sue-former-employee-for-defamation</ref>
In the judges' four page decision Craig was ordered to pay Mrs Jacky Stiekema [Craig v Stiekema Civ2915-404-002882] $17600 in costs following his earlier refusal to discontinue what was described as frivolous litigation [para 12 of the decision] against her by senior barrister Peter McKnight of Wellington firm Langford Law. In the Stiekema case it was concluded Craig sought to obtain emails (that did not exist) between John Stringer (see above) and Mrs Stiekema for ulterior purposes (so Craig could use any material discovered against Stringer elsewhere); ruled a "[[fishing expedition]]" in relation to Craig by Associate Judge Osborne in the Christchurch High Court in yet another Craig proceeding.<ref>[http://defamationupdate.co.nz/sites/all/pdf/2016/Craig-v-Stringer-2016-NZHC-768.pdf See para 11]</ref>
The Judge Harrison decision followed an earlier decision in Wellington by Judge Sharp in December 2016 to strike-out Craig's litigation Craig v Social Media Ltd and Jordan Williams described as "vexatious," "malicious" and "a deception on the court." In both instances Craig is appealing the judgements.<ref>http://www.districtcourts.govt.nz/assets/unsecure/2017-05-08/2017-NZDC-2366-Colin-Craig-v-Social-Media-Consultants-Ltd.pdf</ref> View the full judgement here.<ref>http://www.districtcourts.govt.nz/all-judgments/2016-nzdc-24911-craig-v-social-media-consultants-ltd/</ref>
Jacky Stiekema (described in blog posts by Stringer as "Grandma Quilts" to protect her privacy<ref>[http://worldnews.indywatch.org/archiver/worldnews.indywatch.org/resources/timemachine/2015/329/pacific.html See 14:01]</ref> because she makes quilts and is a grandmother) was an ex-employee of Craig's (a senior Trust Account Manager of several years at Centurion) and had years earlier (2012) successfully taken Craig to the Employment Court for which she was awarded several thousand dollars. It was felt in some quarters that perhaps the more recent litigation was in retaliation for this as it appeared difficult to ascertain Craig's motivation for suing Stiekema and that he had failed "to disclose a serious tort".<ref>see 6 of Harrison 1 September 2017 ref ibid</ref>
At the time of Stiekema's 2012 Employment Court hearing the first negative media publicity emerged about Craig with references in the media to Craig explaining "shortness" being due to "sin" (with biblical allusions to Zaccheus the tax collector) and Stiekema's uncomfortableness with "prayer meetings" run by Craig at the business despite Stiekema's strong personal Christian faith (see STUFF report <ref>http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/6876016/Colin-Craig-preached-shortness-a-sin-claim</ref> which followed years later with the saga detailed above and claims in the media "NZ women are the most promiscuous in the world" during the 2014 election campaign.<ref>http://www.newshub.co.nz/politics/kiwi-women-most-promiscuous--colin-craig-2012050911</ref>
===New litigation, 2017–2018=== In late 2017 Craig was facing additional strike-out applications including a recall and possible strikeout of his Christchurch high court case against John Stringer (mid-October 2017; that was settled by Stringer in January 2017 for zero), still to be heard. He is involved in multiple proceedings including a new suit announced against his former sexual harassment complainant Rachel MacGregor and a counter suit from her against Craig.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Satherley |first1=Dan |title=Colin Craig sues ex-press secretary Rachel MacGregor |url=https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/politics/2017/06/colin-craig-sues-ex-press-secretary-rachel-macgregor.html |accessdate=24 October 2018 |publisher=[[Newshub]] |date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="nzherald.co.nz"/>
On 24 September 2018, Craig dropped his damages claim against MacGregor but stated that he was still pursuing his defamation claim against his former press secretary. MacGregor has also pursued a defamation claim against hwe former employer.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Warhurst |first1=Lucy |title=Colin Craig drops damages claim, but presses ahead with suit against Rachel MacGregor |url=https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/new-zealand/2018/09/colin-craig-drops-damages-claim-but-presses-ahead-with-suit-against-rachel-macgregor.html |accessdate=24 October 2018 |publisher=[[Newshub]] |date=24 September 2018}}</ref> On 25 October, Auckland High Court Judge Kit Toogood ruled that Craig had committed "moderately serious sexual harassment" against MacGregor. He also ruled that Cameron Slater had defamed Craig in five untrue statements but declined to award damages, stating that "the reputational damage which Mr Craig suffered throughout the events traversed at length in this judgment resulted almost entirely from his own actions."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Satherley |first1=Dan |title=Colin Craig 'guilty of moderately serious sexual harassment' against Rachel MacGregor, judge rules |url=https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/politics/2018/10/colin-craig-guilty-of-moderately-serious-sexual-harassment-against-rachel-macgregor-judge-rules.html |accessdate=25 October 2018 |publisher=[[Newshub]] |date=25 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hurley |first1=Sam |title=Judge rules Cameron Slater defamed Colin Craig who sexually harassed Rachel MacGregor |url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12148439 |accessdate=25 October 2018 |publisher=''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' |date=25 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Livingston |first1=Tommy |title=Colin Craig defamed by Cameron Slater, but also found 'guilty' of sexual harassment |url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/108071391/colin-craig-defamed-by-cameron-slater-but-also-found-guilty-of-sexual-harassment |accessdate=25 October 2018 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |date=25 October 2018}}</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Craig, Colin}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Auckland]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Conservative Party of New Zealand politicians]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 2011]] [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:New Zealand Baptists]] [[Category:University of Auckland alumni]] [[Category:Massey University alumni]] [[Category:Unsuccessful candidates in the New Zealand general election, 2014]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2015}} '''Converting companies''' are companies that specialize in combining raw materials such as [[polyester]]s, adhesives, [[silicone]], [[adhesive tape]]s, foams, plastics, felts, rubbers, liners and metals, as well as other materials, to create new products.
Materials such as [[paper]], [[plastic film]], foil and cloth often are produced in long, continuous sheets that are rolled up for more convenient handling and transportation. These rolls of material vary significantly in size and weight — ranging from {{convert|2|-|203|inch|cm|0}} wide and weighing as much as several tons. The converting industry takes these continuous rolls of thin, flat materials — known as webs — threads them through processing machines (such as printing presses, laminating, coating and slitting machines) and converts or changes the web of material into an intermediate form or final product. For example, a converter’s equipment might take a web of plastic film, cut it into lengths, and fuse their edges, thus converting it into plastic bags. This activity is known as web processing.
==Processes== Typical converting processes are coating, laminating and printing. [[Coating]] technologies can include hot melt coating, gravure coating, [[curtain coating]] and slot-die coating. The most common printing techniques are [[flexo]] printing and [[rotogravure]] (gravure) printing. Both print processes are suited to high speed roll-to-roll processing.
Many converting companies will process large diameter, wide rolls of material as this increases the converting efficiency by minimising changes. On completion of the converting process the rolls may be cut into smaller rolls on a [[roll slitting|slitting machine]]. These rolls are then a convenient size for handling on packaging and other machines. Alternatively, the rolls may be sheeted-cut into sheets — as happens in newspaper and book printing. Further processes such as collation may occur after sheeting.
==Web alignment== Web alignment is an important part of a converting operation as a moving web of material has a tendency to track off course and wander out of alignment during the converting processes. To avoid these problems, engineers have developed a variety of automatic web-guiding systems that assure production accuracy and reduce waste. Web-guiding systems typically are positioned just before a critical stage on a converting machine (for example, just before a print station on a printing press).
Each type of [[Web-guiding systems|web guiding system]] uses a sensor to monitor the web position for lateral tracking, and each has an actuator to shift the running web mechanically back on course whenever the sensor detects movement away from the set path. Actuators may be pneumatic or hydraulic cylinders, or some kind of electromechanical device. Because the web may be fragile — particularly at its edge — non-contact sensors are used. These sensors may be [[Pneumatic web guides|pneumatic]], photoelectric, ultrasonic, or infrared. The system’s controls must put the output signals from the sensors in to a form that can drive the actuator. Many controls today are electronic, typically using an amplifier to convert signals from the sensor, then commanding a special servo motor incorporating a lead or ball screw for guiding actuation. The latest web guiding systems have touch screen controls to simplify the setup procedure. Some web guiding systems have been designed specifically for the converting industry.
==Services== Many converters specialize in * Adhesive coating to make [[labels]] and [[adhesive tape]] * Silicone coating to make a [[release liner]] * [[Die (manufacturing)|Die]]-cutting materials into finished parts or labels * Printing services * [[Roll slitting]] of wide webs into narrow webs or coils * Laminating services * [[Vacuum forming]]
==Newer technology== Some converting companies now incorporate electronics in their finished products. For example, converters producing [[RFID]] stock labels must incorporate RFID chips and antenna inlays.<ref name="test">[http://www.abgint.com/news_archive/05_apr_rfid_converter.html Description of an RFID upgrade at a conversion company] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20131016043335/http://www.abgint.com/news_archive/05_apr_rfid_converter.html |date=2013-10-16 }}</ref> The electronic components make up the [[RFID tag]]. The tag stores the information about the items that have been tagged. These converters therefore sometimes incorporate volume electronics manufacturing practices including controlling static electricity, electronic manufacturing test and similar processes. Solving some of the issues of inclusion of materials sensitive to external influences has led to more tech companies embracing roll-based manufacturing processes, with particular success in the lithium ion and solar cell manufacturing sectors.<ref name="lithium">[http://www.universalconvertingequipment.com/lithium-ion-and-solar-cell-manufacturers-increasingly-embracing-web-processes Lithium ion and solar cell manufacturers increasingly embracing converter web processes]</ref>
==Paper converting== {{advert|date=January 2018}} The process of processing pre-cut cartons or "blanks" and folding them into the appropriate shape to become finished packaging containers is known as tray forming or carton erecting. These machines can create, for example, nacho trays, chinese noodle soup boxes, pizza boxes, french fry trays, hamburger clamshells, etc.
==See also== *[[Converting (magazine)]]
